attributes.title: Are training interventions effective at improving the clinical skills of therapists in or following professional postgraduate training?

q1.value: Are training interventions effective at improving the clinical skills of therapists in or following professional postgraduate training?

q3.value: Though psychotherapists receive professional training, it is not clear whether evidence strongly supports how this training is done and whether it is effective. Therefore, this is a systematic literature review of the effectiveness of training interventions for psychotherapists who are either in, or have completed, post-graduate training.

q4.value: Psychotherapeutic training improves the clinical skills, competence and knowledge of trainees

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a systematic literature review.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: The data exists in the form of completed research studies. Initial scoping searches have been completed to ensure that this is a viable research question and project. The results of these searches have not been investigated further than the reading of the study abstracts. A formal literature search has not yet been conducted.

question.value:
The literature will be searched systematically using the Scopus, Medline and PsychINFO databases. A meta-analysis incorporating a systematic search was completed in 2006 (Hill and Lent, 2006), therefore, the search will include studies from 2006. Duplications will be checked and removed.  As only initial scoping has been completed, search terms are not yet finalised. How these are implemented will also vary between databases given the differences in their functionality. At present the planned search terms are:

training OR development

AND therapist OR Psycholog* OR counsel* OR psychotherap* OR "cognitive behavioural therapist"

AND competence OR skill

It is anticipated that these search terms may need to be refined once searching has started. Reasons for adapting may be: unmanageable number of search results returned, irrelevant results returned, additional terms identified through the literature. 

Once this search is complete forward and backwards searches will be completed. Forward searches will be completed by using "As cited by" in google scholar. Backward searches will be completed by looking through reference lists. 

The grey literature will be searched using Google Scholar and dissertations will be searched for using https://ethos.bl.uk/ 

All identified studies will be systemically assessed for inclusion using PRISMA guidelines (Moher, Liberati, Tezlaff, & Altman, 2009). Study selection will be guided by the PICO framework (Schardt, Adams, Owens, Keitz & Fontelo, 2007).
P: Therapists delivering psychotherapy who are either in or have completed postgraduate professional training. 
I: Any intervention which is aimed at improving the clinical skill, knowledge or competence of participants.
C: At minimum studies which have included pre and post measurements. 
O: Outcomes must be assessing clinical skill, knowledge or competence of participants.

Exclusion criteria: 
Studies published before 2006. 
Qualitative studies
Published in a language other than English

Inclusion criteria:
Psychotherapists either in or who have completed professional postgraduate training.

q13.value: As this is a systematic literature sample sizes are not applicable

q15.value: Systematic searches will be conducted on one date which is to be confirmed. Search alerts will be set up, though these will end on 28th February.

question.value: N/A
As this is a systematic literature review this is not yet clear and has possibility to be varied. Outcomes should measure clinical skills, knowledge or competence of psychotherapists.

It is anticipated that the outcome variables will diverge such that meta-analysis techniques cannot be implemented. THerefore the analysis plan for this review is complete a study quality analysis using Down's and Blacks. This will be used to form part of a narrative synthesis of the literature quality and findings.

summary.value:
Stoicism and the good life
What is a good life? Over the course of human history many different answers to this question have been suggest. The ancient Stoics suggested that a good life is a life full of meaning. Late stoic writers such as Epictetus outline a stoicism with the telos (end) of eudaimonia (meaning, flourishing) which can be achieved by living a virtuous life (Ierodiakonou, 2015; Long, 2002). A virtuous life was determined as a life following reason, dedicated to fulfilling ones role in life. Based on this conceptualization of virtue Stoics divided everything into three categories: virtue (acts in accordance with reason), vice (acts contrary to reason), and indifferents (all acts not classified as vice or virtue). While there is no gradient from vice to virtue, Stoics differentiate indifferents in preferred indifferents (enabling reason, such as health), disprefered indifferents (diminishing reasons, such as pain), and absolute indifferents (the colour of your wall). This division implied a rank order of importance virtues are preferable over indifferents, indifferents over vices (Inwood, 2003). This leads to adherents of Stoicism sometimes prioritizing acts over hedonic wellbeing or health if they enable reason and are beneficial to eudaimonic wellbeing (Becker, 2003, 2017).
While few people explicitly follow stoic doctrine in modern times, stoic ideology is implicitly embraced by many individuals. Stoic ideology has long been endorsed by military personnel (Sherman, 2011). Outside the military field stoic thought has profoundly influenced Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (Robertson, 2016, 2019) and plays an important role in the treatment of anxiety and depression. Stoic philosophy has long influenced psychology, but little attention has been paid how individuals differ in their endorsement of stoic ideologies (for a thorough review of ancient stoicism and modern revivals we recommend Becker, 2017). Initial scales measuring stoicism mostly focused on a single dimensional construct assessed by past behaviours (Pathak et al., 2017). Recently a scale of stoic ideology has been developed, the Pathak-Wieten Stoicism Ideology Scale (PWSIS; Pathak et al., 2017), allowing for the assessment of individuals implicit endorsement of stoic ideology. This scale assesses stoic ideology comprised of four facets, Stoic Taciturnity (The belief that emotions should not be expressed), Stoic Serenity (The belief that strong emotions should not be felt), Stoic Endurance (The belief that physical suffering should be endured), and Death Acceptance (Accepting mortality, rather than fearing it).
So, what does this stoic ideology imply for individuals’ wellbeing? Past research has shown negative relationship of stoicism and life satisfaction as well as positive relationships between stoicism and depression (Bei et al., 2013; Murray et al., 2008). Overall, this might lead to the conclusion that embracing stoic ideologies reduces wellbeing. While this might be true for hedonic wellbeing, Stoicism is an explicitly eudaimonic theory of wellbeing prioritizing meaning over pleasure. Currently no research is available that directly compares the effects of stoic ideology on hedonic and eudaimonic well-being. In the current study we aim to address this to further the understanding of stoic ideology as contributor to wellbeing.
We propose two hypotheses for the current research. First, given the conceptualization of Stoicism as eudaimonic theory of wellbeing, prioritizing eudaimonic wellbeing over hedonic wellbeing, we expect individuals that endorse a stoic ideology to show a greater orientation to eudaimonic rather than hedonic wellbeing. 
Hypothesis 1: Stoicism is positively related to eudaimonic orientation and negatively to hedonic orientation to happiness.
	Second, based on previous studies that found negative effects of Stoicism on hedonic wellbeing, we expect that individuals embracing stoic ideology have less hedonic wellbeing, but higher eudaimonic wellbeing.
Hypothesis 2: Stoicism is negatively related to hedonic wellbeing and positively related to eudaimonic wellbeing 
Method
Participants
We will sample 400 undergraduate psychology students taking part in an introductory course to psychology. This sample size would give us the ability to detect a two-sided effect of r = .14 with a power of .80 and an α error probability of .05. Because the endorsement of stoic ideology was strongly tied to a male gender identity in the past, we will aim to sample an even number of participants identifying as male and female. These students will fill out the provided measure as part of a larger survey pack examining their personal values and mindfulness. 
Procedure
Participants will be offered the study through an online portal and give the ability to complete the study online in their own time.
Measures
	Demographics. Participants will be asked to report their self-identified gender identity and current age.
Stoic Ideology. We will measure stoic ideology using the twelve item Pathak-Wieten Stoicism Ideology Scale (PWSIS; Pathak et al. 2017). The scale measures four constructs Endurance (“I expect myself to hide my aches and pains from others.”), Taciturnity (“I don’t believe in talking about my personal problems.”), Serenity (“I would prefer to be unemotional.”), and Death Acceptance (“I would not allow myself to be bothered by the fear of death.”). All items will be measured on a scale from 1-(“Disagree”) to 5-(“Agree”). Before the main analysis all items will be recoded to range from -2 to +2 following the original scoring instructions.
Orientation to Happiness. We will measure participants orientation to happiness using the eighteen item orientation to happiness questionnaire (Peterson et al., 2005). This questionnaire assesses three dimensions: “A life of pleasure”, “A life of meaning”, “A life of engagement”. The six items per scale are rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (“Very much unlike me”) to 7 (“Very much like me”). Example items for each dimension are: “. Life is too short to postpone the pleasures it can provide.” (Pleasure), “I have a responsibility to make the world a better place.” (Meaning), and “I am always very absorbed in what I do.” (Engagement).
Eudaimonic Wellbeing.
Flourishing. The Flourishing scale is a eight-item measure assessing individuals self-perceived success in relationships as well as self-esteem, purpose, and optimism (Diener et al., 2010). Participants responded on a Likert scale from 1-(“Strongly disagree”) to 7-(“Strongly agree”). An example item is, “I am a good person and live a good life”.
Meaning in Life. The Meaning in Life Questionnaire (Steger et al., 2006) assesses the presence and search for meaning with ten items measures on a seven point Likert-scale ranging from 1-(“Absolutely untrue”) to 7-(“Absolutely true”). To measure eudaimonic wellbeing we will use the five item presence of meaning subscale. An example item is, “I understand my life’s meaning”.
Hedonic Wellbeing.
Satisfaction with life. The Satisfaction With Life Scale (Diener, Emmons, Larsen, & Griffin, 1985) is a five-item measure of present, global life satisfaction, which comprise a cognitive judgment of a person’s quality of life. Participants responded on a Likert scale from 1-(“Strongly disagree”) to 7-(“Strongly agree”). An example item is, “I am satisfied with my current life”.
Subjective happiness. The subjective happiness scale (Lyubomirsky & Lepper, 1999) is a four-item measure of global happiness measured on a Likert scale from 1 to 7. The item anchors are relative to the items, first pair of items are anchored at 1-(“Less happy”) and 7-(More happy), the second pair of items are anchored at 1-(Not at all) to 7-(A great deal). 
The classification of the scales as hedonic or eudaimonic is based on previous large scale research and reviews (Cooke et al., 2016; Disabato et al., 2016).
Data Analysis
Data Exclusion and Processing
	We will exclude participants that did not finish the survey, as this can be interpreted as a withdrawal of consent. We will create an average score of hedonic and eudaimonic wellbeing for each participant across the individual measures after rescoring negatively worded items (Item four for subjective happiness, and item nine for meaning in life). 
Equivalence Testing.
	Because previous research has indicated substantial gender differences in the mean score of stoic ideology, we will examine the equivalence of the PWSIS between male and female participants. We will use a multi-group confirmatory factor analysis to test for the equivalence of the structure, loadings, and intercepts. We will follow previously recommended guidelines (Fischer & Karl, 2019). Equivalence between the differently constrained models will be supported by a drop of the confirmatory fit indicator (CFI) < .01.
Hypotheses Testing
	To test hypothesis one, we will create a SEM path-model in which the observed score of stoicism will predict the observed scores of hedonic and eudaimonic orientation to happiness. Our hypothesis will be supported if we find a significant negative relationship between stoic ideology and hedonic orientation to happiness and a positive relationship between stoic ideology and eudaimonic orientation to happiness. This would indicate that stoic ideology is indeed a eudaimonic approach to wellbeing as expected by its philosophical underpinnings.
To test hypothesis two, we will create a SEM path-model in which the observed score of stoicism will predict the observed scores of hedonic and eudaimonic wellbeing. Our hypothesis will be supported if we find a significant negative relationship between stoic ideology and hedonic wellbeing a positive relationship between stoic ideology and eudaimonic wellbeing. This would indicate that stoic ideology has differential effects on wellbeing, potentially leading individuals to prioritizing meaning over pleasure in life.
Exploratory Analyses
	We propose a number of exploratory analysis, extending the current analysis beyond the proposed hypotheses. First we will examine the effect of the individual facets of stoic ideology on the outcome measure to identify facets that might be especially important. Further we will examine the effect of stoicism on the orientation to happiness subscale measuring a life of engagement, because neither theory nor empirical evidence predict a clear relationship we want to provide explorative evidence. Last, we want to examine the relationship between stoicism and search for meaning. 
References
Becker, L. C. (2003). Human Health and Stoic Moral Norms. The Journal of Medicine and Philosophy, 28(2), 221–238. https://doi.org/10.1076/jmep.28.2.221.14206
Becker, L. C. (2017). A new stoicism. Princeton University Press.
Bei, B., Bryant, C., Gilson, K.-M., Koh, J., Gibson, P., Komiti, A., Jackson, H., & Judd, F. (2013). A prospective study of the impact of floods on the mental and physical health of older adults. Aging & Mental Health, 17(8), 992–1002. https://doi.org/10.1080/13607863.2013.799119
Cooke, P. J., Melchert, T. P., & Connor, K. (2016). Measuring Well-Being. The Counseling Psychologist, 44(5), 730–757. https://doi.org/10.1177/0011000016633507
Diener, E., Wirtz, D., Tov, W., Kim-Prieto, C., Choi, D., Oishi, S., & Biswas-Diener, R. (2010). New Well-being Measures: Short Scales to Assess Flourishing and Positive and Negative Feelings. Social Indicators Research, 97(2), 143–156. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11205-009-9493-y
Disabato, D. J., Goodman, F. R., Kashdan, T. B., Short, J. L., & Jarden, A. (2016). Different types of well-being? A cross-cultural examination of hedonic and eudaimonic well-being. Psychological Assessment, 28(5), 471–482. https://doi.org/10.1037/pas0000209
Fischer, R., & Karl, J. A. (2019). A primer to (cross-cultural) multi-group invariance testing possibilities in R. Frontiers in Psychology, 10, 1507. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2019.01507
Ierodiakonou, K. (2015). How Feasible Is the Stoic Conception of Eudaimonia? In The Quest for the Good Life (pp. 183–196). Oxford University Press. https://doi.org/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780198746980.003.0010
Inwood, B. (2003). The Cambridge companion to the Stoics. In The Cambridge Companion to the Stoics. Cambridge University Press. https://doi.org/10.1017/CCOL052177005X
Long, A. A. (2002). Epictetus. Oxford University Press. https://doi.org/10.1093/0199245568.001.0001
Lyubomirsky, S., & Lepper, H. S. (1999). A measure of subjective happiness: Preliminary reliability and construct validation. Social Indicators Research, 46(2), 137–155. https://doi.org/10.1023/A:1006824100041
Murray, G., Judd, F., Jackson, H., Fraser, C., Komiti, A., Pattison, P., Wearing, A., & Robins, G. (2008). Big boys don’t cry: An investigation of stoicism and its mental health outcomes. Personality and Individual Differences, 44(6), 1369–1381. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2007.12.005
Pathak, E. B., Wieten, S. E., & Wheldon, C. W. (2017). Stoic beliefs and health: development and preliminary validation of the Pathak-Wieten Stoicism Ideology Scale. BMJ Open, 7(11), e015137. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2016-015137
Peterson, C., Park, N., & Seligman, M. E. P. (2005). Orientations to happiness and life satisfaction: The full life versus the empty life. Journal of Happiness Studies, 6(1), 25–41. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10902-004-1278-z
Robertson, D. (2016). The Stoic inﬂuence on modern psychotherapy. In J. Sellars (Ed.), The Routledge Handbook of the Stoic Tradition (pp. 394–408). Routledge. https://doi.org/10.4324/9781315771588-39
Robertson, D. (2019). The Philosophy of Cognitive-Behavioural Therapy (CBT) : Stoic Philosophy as Rational and Cognitive Psychotherapy. https://doi.org/10.4324/9780429268700
Sherman, N. (2011). Stoic Warriors: The Ancient Philosophy Behind the Military Mind. In Stoic Warriors: The Ancient Philosophy Behind the Military Mind. Oxford University Press. https://doi.org/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780195315912.001.0001
Steger, M. F., Frazier, P., Oishi, S., & Kaler, M. (2006). The meaning in life questionnaire: Assessing the presence of and search for meaning in life. Journal of Counseling Psychology, 53, 80–93. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-0167.53.1.80

attributes.title: Participatory action for long-term arsenic safe drinking water consumption (PACT)

q1.value: Participatory action for long-term arsenic safe water consumption (PACT)

q3.value:
Drinking and cooking water can be unsafe due to natural (e.g. geogenic Arsenic in groundwater) or anthropogenic contamination (e.g. microbiological pollution) and puts people at risk of adverse health related consequences. 

Safe water infrastructure can mitigate adverse health effects (Pokhrel, Bhandari, & Viraraghavan, 2009), provided safe water is collected and consumed from there. However, safe water infrastructure is often not used or maintained in the long term (e.g. Naiga & Penker, 2004). In this study, we test whether individual (habit) and social factors (psychological ownership) can promote the acceptance (i.e. attitudes and commitment), use, and functionality of safe water infrastructure. 

Psychological ownership (PO), i.e. the feeling that something is mine or ours (Pierce, Kostova, & Dirks, 2001), is a concept from organisational psychology. It has also been suggested as a key factor related to the low acceptance, use and maintenance of safe drinking water infrastructure (Marks, Onda, & Davis, 2013; Contzen & Marks, 2018). For example, Marks & Davis (2012) showed that the concept of PO is positively associated with use of a safe water source. However, experimental evidence on causality of this relationship is lacking.
Psychological ownership theory suggests three routes, through which PO may be fostered. First, through perceived control over the target. Second, through intimately knowing the target. Third, through investing the self in the target (e.g. through investing money or time and effort; Pierce, Kostova, & Dirks, 2001). Persons with greater PO for a target, in turn, are assumed to show more positive attitudes, and greater commitment for the target (Pierce et al., 2001). Concerning the context of health-related infrastructure, it is unknown, whether similar routes and consequences are applicable as in the organisational context. It is also unknown, whether PO leads to better acceptance, behaviour change (i.e. safe water consumption), and long-term functionality of safe water infrastructure.

Functional safe water infrastructure additionally has to be used in order to mitigate the risk of health related consequences. Therefore, a change in people’s individual routines in water collection behaviour is required (Steg & Vlek, 2008). Changing one’s water collection behaviour to a new source in the long term requires discontinuing old habits (collecting water from an unsafe source) and forming new habits (collecting water from a safe source) (Orbell & Verplanken, 2015). Habit is defined “… as a process by which a stimulus generates an impulse to act as a result of a learned stimulus-response association” (Gardner, 2015, p. 277). Due to the automaticity, habit is assumed to have long-lasting effects on behaviour change. A previous study on the promotion of arsenic-safe water consumption used commitment-based behaviour change techniques (Inauen & Mosler, 2014, 2016; Inauen, Tobias, & Mosler, 2014) that should promote habit development (Tobias, 2009). The intervention showed promising results to promote medium-term use of arsenic-safe water sources (Inauen & Mosler, 2016). However, it has not been tested whether the interventions promote long-term safe water consumption via habit formation. Further, the long-term effect has only been investigated for a period < 1 year.  

In a cluster-randomized controlled trial (c-RCT), we test whether PO for safe water infrastructure promotes acceptance, use, and functionality of the infrastructure in the long-term, and whether habit for safe water collection can additionally promote the use of this infrastructure in the long-term.

q4.value:
1)	Can a psychological ownership intervention promote acceptance (i.e. positive attitudes and stronger commitment), use, and functionality of safe water infrastructure?
•	In the short term, participants in the PO arms will show greater acceptance (attitude: H1a; commitment: H1b), and greater use (H1c) compared to controls. (No difference in functionality is expected short term, as short-term functionality of infrastructure is assumed high in all groups). 
•	In the long term, participants in the psychological ownership intervention arms will show more positive attitudes (H1d), stronger commitment (H1e), greater use (H1f), and greater number of functional safe water taps (H1g) than participants in control arms. At the community level, more functional safe water infrastructure will be found in PO arms than in control arms (H1h).

2)	Can a habit intervention promote the use of safe water infrastructure in the long term?
•	Participants in the habit intervention arms will use safe water infrastructure more often short-term (H2a) and long-term (H2b) than participants in the control arms.

3)	Is a combined intervention of psychological ownership and habit more effective than the psychological ownership or habit intervention alone to promote the acceptance, use, and functionality of safe water infrastructure?
•	In the short term, participants in the combined intervention arm will show more positive attitudes (H3a), stronger commitment (H3b), and greater use (H3c) of safe water infrastructure compared to those with PO or habit interventions alone. 
•	In the long term, participants in the combined intervention arm will exhibit more positive attitudes (H3d), stronger commitment (H3e), use (H3f), and a greater number of functional safe water taps (H3g) compared to those with PO or habit intervention alone. At the community level, in the long term, more functional safe water infrastructure are found in combined arms than in PO or control arms alone (H3h).

4)	Can psychological ownership for safe water infrastructure be promoted through the psychological ownership intervention?
•	Psychological ownership is greater in PO intervention arms compared to controls in the short term (H4a) and long term (H4b).

5)	Does psychological ownership mediate the effects of the intervention on the outcomes?
•	Psychological ownership at midline mediates the relationship between the PO intervention and acceptance (H5a), use (H5b), and functionality (H5c) of safe water infrastructure at endline.

6)	Can habit for safe water collection behaviour be promoted through reminders, implementation intentions, and public commitment?
•	Habit for safe water collection is stronger in habit intervention arms, compared to controls, in the short term (H6a) and long term (H6b).

7)	Does habit mediate the effects of the intervention on behaviour change?
•	Habit at short term (H7a) and at long term (H7b) mediates the relationship between the intervention and use of safe water infrastructure at endline.

Based on the assumptions of temporal self-regulation theory (Hall & Fong, 2007), we also investigate the source of contamination as a determinant of behaviour change, and potential moderator of intervention effects (microbiological contamination has immediate and arsenic contamination has delayed health consequences):

8)	Do people at risk of immediately impaired health (microbiological contaminated water) differ in their change of water collection behaviour from people at  risk of delayed impaired health (arsenic contaminated water)?
•	Persons with risk of microbiological contamination in household water at baseline show a greater probability of good water quality at midline (H9a) or at endline (H9b) compared to persons with arsenic contaminated household water at baseline..

9)	Is microbiological risk a moderator of the intervention effect on behaviour change?
•	Microbiological risk at baseline moderates the relationship between the intervention and use of safe water infrastructure at midline and endline. Persons with risk of microbiological contamination in household water at baseline show a greater increase in the probability of good household water quality in the intervention vs. control arms at midline (H9a) and at endline (H9b) compared to persons with arsenic contaminated household water at baseline.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study design is a single blind factorial cluster-randomized controlled trial with repeated measures (see Fig. 1), testing the effect of psychological ownership and habit on the acceptance, use and functionality of safe water infrastructure. A total of K = 64 habitations, and N = 1920 participants will be recruited. The outcomes are measured for assessment of medium term effects one month after interventions (post-interventions) and for long term effects at 16 months after interventions (follow-up).

q9.value: Because of the organisation of the water supply infrastructure in Bihar, the interventions are randomised at the cluster level. Clusters are habitations (areas in a village, supplied by one safe water infrastructure unit). To perform randomization, a list of the clusters and intervention arms is generated in Excel after the baseline survey. The four intervention arms are then randomly assigned to habitations using the command “random number generation”.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Baseline data collection is ongoing. The already collected baseline data has not been observed by the researchers.

question.value:
Clusters (i.e. habitations) are selected based on the planning of installation of safe water infrastructure units. Habitations are only selected if no work on the installation has been done at time of baseline and if safe water infrastructure is intended to be installed within 6 months.

At participant recruitment, arsenic contamination of household drinking water is measured and sanitary inspection of the household drinking water source is performed. Afterwards, households are immediately informed about the results, i.e. possible risks, and possible mitigation options. Persons responsible for drinking water collection of eligible households (see inclusion criteria below), are then asked to be interviewed:

The interviewers explain the content of the study using a standardised informed consent form, give potential participants the opportunity and time to ask questions. Further, they inform that participation is voluntary and that the survey will contain questions related to your drinking water behaviour and your and your communities thoughts and feelings towards drinking water consumption and handling. To participate, potential participants have to agree with their signature or thumb print. Participants are not being reimbursed at any point for their participation.

q13.value:
Every intervention arm includes k=16 habitations. In every habitation, n=30 participants will be recruited. The allocation of clusters to the four different intervention arms is not communicated to the intervention team until the interventions are implemented. In total, N=1920 participants are recruited in total K=64 habitations.

Inclusion criteria at cluster level: Habitations in rural areas in Bhagalpur district (Bihar, India), where
-	The Public Health Engineering Department (PHED, i.e. government entity responsible for safe water provision) has planned to install safe drinking water infrastructure until the end of March 2020.
-	No construction activities of PHED on safe drinking water infrastructure has taken place at baseline survey.
-	No non-government organisation (NGO) has been working in the area in the last 12 months.

Inclusion criteria for participants in those habitations is:
-	Household drinking water at risk of either arsenic (c(As) > 10 ppb) or microbiological contamination (WHO > 8) or both contaminations at time of baseline survey.
-	Person is responsible for drinking or cooking water collection in the household.
-	Age 18 or older.

A random sample of participants is recruited by interviewers, using the random walk method (Hoffmeyer-Zlotnik, 2003).

q14.value:
The sample size was calculated in GPower (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) following the guidelines of Rutterford, Coppa, & Eldridge (2015):
-	Cohen’s d = 0.35 (assumption based on Chen et al., 2007)
-	Design-effect due to nested study design (Eldridge, Ashby, & Kerry, 2006) with
N=(1+(m-1)*ICC)
-	ICC is assumed to be very low (0.01 – 0.2) based on previous studies conducted in India (Patil et al., 2014; Pagel et al., 2011; Auplish et al., 2017).
-	Attrition of 25% and expected intervention uptake of 80%, minimum cluster size at baseline is 30 participants and minimum number of clusters is 64 habitations. The minimal number of clusters is defined according to Raudenbush et al. (2011).

question.value: Psychological ownership for the safe water infrastructure and habit for its use are the interventional constructs in this 2x2 factorial c-RCT design.

All psycho-social data are collected during structured computer-assisted personal interviews (CAPI), using tablet-based questionnaires and the open data kit software (https://opendatakit.org/ ; Anokwa, Hartung, Brunette, Lerer, & Borriello, 2009). Measures for intervention fidelity and uptake are not included in this overview, as they will be developed together with the local partners after the baseline survey. See Table 1 attached: Overview over all measures used to assess primary and secondary outcomes on cluster and participant level.

Because of the hierarchical data (participants nested in habitations), multilevel models with random intercepts and random slopes are used to analyse the data. No covariates are included a priori into the models, but we will conduct sensitivity analyses including covariates such as socio-economic standard etc.



Research questions 1,2, and 3: Main and interactive effects of psychological ownership and habit on outcomes.
For each outcome and time point, a multilevel regression model will be fitted, using either a linear (for continuous) or logistic function (for binary outcomes). Predictors will be three intervention variables: two dummy variables (one for each intervention) and their product, to model the main and interactive effects of the ownership and habit intervention. Random intercepts and random slopes will be fitted to model the variability of outcomes and intervention effects between clusters (i.e. habitations), using an exchangeable covariance matrix.

Research questions 4-7: Mediators of the intervention effect on outcomes
For each outcome, a 2-1-1 multilevel mediation analysis will be performed, accounting for the variability of the mediation effects between clusters (e.g. Harter, Inauen, & Mosler, 2019). X is the respective intervention (ownership or habit) vs. control arm, M is self-reported psychological ownership or habit respectively, and Y is the respective outcome (e.g. self-reported use of safe water source). Random intercepts and random slopes will be fitted to model the variability of outcomes and effects between clusters (i.e. habitations), using an exchangeable covariance matrix.
 
Research questions 8 and 9: Moderators of the intervention effect on outcomes
For each time point, a multilevel regression model will be fitted using safe water collection behaviour as the outcome. Predictors will be two dummy variables (one for each intervention) and their product, and the moderator variable, i.e. the type of baseline contamination of household drinking water (microbiological vs. arsenic) to model the main and interactive effect of contamination type with the intervention on the outcome. Random intercepts and random slopes will be fitted to model the variability of outcomes and intervention effects between clusters (i.e. habitations), using an exchangeable covariance matrix.

q22.value: Data points will only be excluded if there is significant logical inconsistency or when participants explicitly ask for deleting their data.

q23.value: Missing data or incomplete data will be estimated by multiple imputations (Sterne et al., 2009).

Random intercepts and random slopes will be fitted to model the variability of outcomes and intervention effects between clusters (i.e. habitations), using an exchangeable covariance matrix.

sample.value: We will test as many children as possible within the time frame available for data collection (2 month). Children will be tested twice with the same tasks on different days. Relations between measures will only be explored if we collect data from more than 40 children (20 3-year-olds, 20 4-year-olds). Children will be between 3.0 and 5.0 years of age and will be recruited in kindergartens in a mid-sized city in Germany.

analyses.value:
For each age group, we will compare the performance in each measure to a level expected by chance (50% correct - 33% correct for discourse continuity) using t-tests. To do so, we will aggregate performance across all trials children receive in a particular condition (across test sessions). 

To test for developmental change in each measure, we will fit a Bayesian generalized linear mixed model to the trial by trial data using the r package brms with default priors. The model has the following structure:

correct ~ age + trial + (trial | id) + (age | item)

Correct: whether or not the correct object was chosen. 
Age: numerical age in years (centered)
Trial: test trial continuous across test days (centered)
Id: participant id
Item: item id

For each measure, we will compare this model to a reduced model without age as a predictor.  

Retest reliability: 

We will aggregate the data by participant and test day and use Pearson correlations to assess retest reliability of each measure. 

Analysis across measures:

If we collect data for more than 40 children (20 3-year-olds, 20 4-year-olds), we will explore the relations between the different measures. In each case, measures will be aggregated within participants across all test trials. We will conduct the following analysis: 

Pairwise correlations:
We will compute pairwise correlations between all measures. Prediction is that pragmatics tasks should correlate higher among each other than with card sorting. 

Internal consistency: 
We will investigate internal consistency of the scale by computing Cronabch’s alpha for subsets of all measures, always leaving on measure out. The prediction is that consistency is highest when the card sorting measure is not included. 

Exploratory factor analysis: 
To investigate the dimensionality of the measures more directly, we will conduct an exploratory factor analysis.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded if they don't finish at least two measures or one measure twice.

dependent.value:
Dependent variable in the pragmatics tasks is whether or not children choose the “correct” object as the referent of the novel word. By measure: 

Mutual exclusivity: Correct = unfamiliar object (as opposed to a familiar one).  

Informativeness: Correct = object that is less frequent in context.

Ad hoc: Correct = object that is less frequent in context.

Discourse continuity: Object that belongs to the same category as previously mentioned objects.

Card sorting: Correct = card is sorted according to the dimension that the experimenter specified.

Material is presented as a picture book on an iPad. An experimenter guides children through each task. For the pragmatics tasks, the speakers are cartoon animal characters that “talk” via pre-recorded utterances that are played back to the child. For the card sorting task, the experimenter gives the child instructions. In each task, children respond by touching objects on the screen. These touches are recorded.

conditions.value: Children receive all tasks in the same order, with the same order of items in each task. Each of the pragmatics tasks has five trials. The card sorting task has 6 pre-switch trials and 6 post-switch trials. Children will repeat the entire procedure on a different day.

hypothesis.value:
This study investigates pragmatic inference as a psychological construct and addresses two main questions:
 
How reliable are measures of children’s pragmatic abilities? 
Is performance in different measures related to one another? 

We will use four different measures of children’s pragmatic abilities. Each measure is based on published work and has been tested using the same basic stimuli in the same age range, but in a different language (previous: English, here: German). The four measures are: 

Mutual exclusivity: Children can infer the meaning of a word by assuming that novel words go with novel objects (modeled after Markman & Wachtel, 1988)
Informativeness: Children can infer the meaning of a novel word by assuming that the speaker is informative (modeled after Frank & Goodman, 2014). 
Ad hoc implicature: Children can identify the referent of a known word by assuming that the speaker is informative (modeled after Yoon & Frank, 2019).
Discourse continuity: Children can identify therefernt of an ambiguous pronoun by reasoning about the topic under discussion (after Bohn, et al, under review).

In addition, we administer a fifth measure of an unrelated construct: 

Card sorting: Children sort cards according to one dimension and are then told to switch and sort the same cards according to a different dimension (modeled after Zelazo, 2006)

The purpose of the last measure is to see if shared variance between pragmatic measures are better explained by general cognitive abilities rather than specific pragmatic abilities. 

To assess the reliability of each measure, children will be tested twice in each task. 

In a previous study, we collected data for a different set of tasks. Mutual exclusivity and Card sorting were also part of this previous round of data collection.

attributes.title: Structural brain similarity in mother-child dyads

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value: Structural brain similarity in mother-child dyads: investigating the sulcal morphology of the occipitotemporal sulcus

sample.value: All data collected by August 2020 over both sites will be included in the analyses. No formal analyses will be performed before August 2020.

analyses.value:
Sulcal morphology analyses will focus on the left and right OTS. Analyses will be performed using BrainVISA software (http://brainvisa.info/). For the characterization of the OTS, we will use the protocol put forward by Cachia and colleagues (2018). The sulcal pattern of left and right OTS will be characterized as “interrupted” when the OTS has interruptions and as “continuous” otherwise. To investigate the effect of the anatomical location of the OTS interruption, we will also identify whether the interruption is located in the posterior part of the sulcus, which is thought to host the Visual Word Form Area hub in the neural reading network, or in the anterior part of the sulcus. An anatomical criterion, specifically the y-coordinate of the posterior extremity of the brainstem, will be used as a limit to define the anterior and posterior part of the OTS. 

Chi-square goodness of fit tests performed in Jamovi (https://www.jamovi.org) will be computed to assess whether the presence / absence of an interruption in mothers more frequently co-occur with the presence / absence of an interruption in the child, respectively. Chi-square goodness of fit tests analyses will be run for both left and right OTS. We will correct for multiple comparisons using a Bonferroni correction.

outliers.value:
To ensure sufficient data quality, we will exclude any mother-child pairs for whom either one or both structural scans show too much movement for clear labelling.
In the case of mothers who participated with multiple children, we will use a multi-step procedure to select which child will be included. If a lack of data quality makes a scan of a child unusable, we will use their sibling’s data in the analyses. However, if scans of multiple children are usable for analyses, we will select the child whose age and gender balance those respective distributions best. 
As a robustness check, we will rerun the analyses using the data of the excluded siblings with usable scans.

dependent.value:
Data from a total number of 70 families (81 children/70 mothers, total mother-child sample of N=151) have been collected in Switzerland and Canada thus far. All children and mothers were asked to participate in two testing sessions that either took place at the facilities of the Department of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry (UPK Basel) and University Hospital in Basel, Switzerland, or at the Brain and Mind Institute at the University of Western Ontario, Canada. At both sites, behavioral assessments as well as structural neuroimaging data were obtained. Additional site-specific functional neuroimaging tasks not relevant to this preregistration were implemented as well, resulting in an approximate total duration of testing sessions of about 2-2.5 hours including breaks. Each site followed age-adequate and child-friendly neuroimaging protocols. 

At each site, a behavioral testing battery was administered in line with individual ongoing developmental projects (Switzerland: Theory of Mind, Canada: Reading and arithmetic). At both sites, intelligence data were collected using the Matrix Reasoning and Vocabulary subtests of the Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence (Petermann and Petermann 2011). For the common project, we will report standardized verbal and non-verbal IQ measures for all.

Whole-brain structural MPRAGE images were acquired on a SIEMENS 3T Prisma MR scanner using a 20-channel head coil (transverse slice orientation, interleaved acquisition) using the following specifications: Voxel size: 1.0×1.0×1.0 mm; TR = 1900 ms; TE = 3.42 ms; TA = 4.26; flip angle = 9 degrees; field of view = 256 x 256 mm, 192 slices with a slice thickness of 1.00 mm. Structural image acquisition duration is of 4.26 minutes (Switzerland). In Canada, images were also acquired on a SIEMENS 3T Prisma MR scanner, but with a 32-channel head coil and sagittal slice orientation. The use of the same MR scanner at both sites ensures comparability of measurements and site comparisons will be conducted within one travelling participant that is scanned at both sites, but not included in the final analyses.

hypothesis.value:
Reading ability is strongly heritable. Furthermore, parental reading skills and the home literacy environment children grow up in are associated with reading development. Overall, there is strong evidence for genetic and environmental effects on reading skills. However, the precise mechanisms of these interactive processes are challenging to study, and a comparison of structural brain correlates for the reading network between parents and children has not yet been conducted. The main aim of the proposed research activity is to investigate structural brain similarity between children and their mothers in a crucial hub of the neural reading network: the occipitotemporal cortex. 

Recent studies have provided evidence that the sulcal pattern of the occipitotemporal sulcus (OTS) is associated with reading abilities in children (Borst et al., 2016) and in adults (Cachia et al., 2017). Specifically, the presence of an interruption in the posterior part of the left OTS has been found to be associated with better reading abilities. A posterior interruption in left OTS might hold an advantage in reading by reflecting an underlying difference in the size of white matter tracts (e.g., higher number, greater myelination ...) connecting the Visual Word Form Area, located in that posterior segment of the OTS (see e.g., Dehaene & Cohen, 2011), with the rest of reading network. Sulcal characterizations are assumed to be relatively stable from birth throughout the lifespan and are therefore assumed to be more genetically influenced. Due to the stability of sulcal features, the investigation of the sulcal pattern of the occipitotemporal area is ideal to investigate structural brain similarities between children and their biological mothers.

We hypothesize that mother-child dyads will exhibit familial similarity of the brain structure within the reading network as reflected by similarity of sulcal morphology indices of the left OTS. We predict that children whose mothers have a posterior interruption in the left OTS will be more likely to show a posterior interruption themselves, while the absence of such an interruption in mothers will be predictive of an absence in their children as well. We will investigate this in the right OTS too, as a control measure.

attributes.title: The impact of sarcopenia on postoperative complications and mortality after major emergency abdominal surgery
attributes.description: This cohort study aimed to investigate the associations between preoperative sarcopenia and postoperative complications and death after major emergency abdominal surgery

q1.value: The impact of sarcopenia on postoperative complications and mortality after major emergency abdominal surgery

q3.value: Sarcopenia, defined as loss of muscle mass, is often seen in relation to pre-existing comorbidity, age, and physical weakening. In elective surgery, the degree of sarcopenia has been correlated to increased risk of complications, increased postoperative length of stay, and increased risk of long term mortality. The consequences of sarcopenia in major emergency abdominal surgery is sparsely examined.

q4.value: The hypothesis of this study was to examine which specific postoperative complications patients with preoperative sarcopenia develop and how these postoperative complications differ from the complications patients without sarcopenia develops.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A retrospective cohort study was conducted including patients that underwent major emergency abdominal surgery at a single surgical center

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Major emergency abdominal surgery included open, laparoscopic, or laparoscopically assisted procedures performed on the stomach, small bowel, large bowel, or rectum within 72 hours after admission to the Department of Surgery for conditions such as perforation, ischemia, bleeding, adhesiolysis, deep infection, or obstruction. Patients who underwent multiple surgical procedures were eligible for inclusion if the primary surgical procedure was includable. Surgical procedures in relation to appendix, gallbladder, liver, spleen, or trauma surgery were not includable. Patients with more than one emergent admission during the study period, only the first admission was included.

q13.value: No sample size was used due to the exploratory nature of the study.

question.value: Sarcopenia was evaluated by the preoperative CT scan upon the relevant emergency admission. Patients without a preoperative CT scan, therefore, were excluded from this study. Only CT-scans within seven days of emergency admission were deemed relevant for sarcopenia evaluation. The preoperative CT scan closest to the surgical procedure was selected if several CT scans were available. Sarcopenia was defined as earlier defined 4 (5, 6) by evaluating the total psoas area (TPA) at the primary axial level of the third lumbar vertebrae where both vertebral spine were visible. The circumference of the psoas muscles and the Houndsfield unit of the marked area were registered to secure that muscle and not vessels, fat infiltration, or other tissue were examined. TPA was adjusted for height and weight and reported as mm2/m2.  Sarcopenia cut-off levels were  <385 mm2/m2 for females and <524 mm2/m2 for males, as reported 4. The radiologic evaluation was performed independently and blinded by two certified radiologists. A sample of 100 CT scans were randomly selected and evaluated by both radiologists.

The primary outcome was the occurrence and distribution of specific complications (graded by Clavien-Dindo) among patients with radiologic verified preoperative sarcopenia. The secondary outcomes included 90-day mortality, 360-day mortality, and length of stay (days).

The study population will be stratified into patients with sarcopenia and without sarcopenia based on CT evaluations. The distribution of data will be examined with histograms and Q-Q plots. Continuous data presented by the median and interquartile range (IQR) and categorical data by proportions and percentages. 

Categorical data are analyzed by chi-square or Fischer's exact test where applicable and continuous data by students t-test or Mann-Whitney where applicable. Interobserver correlation between radiological sarcopenia evaluations will be evaluated by Kappa statistics. 

Univariate analysis of specific postoperative complications stratified by sarcopenia will be performed to identify possible postoperative complications that occur more frequently among patients with sarcopenia. Based on these univariate analyses we will attempt to perform multivariate logistic regression models (forced entry adjustment) with focus on 

- specific surgical complications (adjusted for age, sex, BMI, active smoking, intraoperative contamination (Mangram), and diabetes), 

- respiratory complications (including respiratory failure, pneumonia, pleural effusion) (adjusted for age, sex, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, active smoking, laparoscopic surgery, and BMI), and 

- infectious complications (adjusted for age, sex, and diabetes). Especially, we will see if patients with preoperative 

Finally, we plan a multivariate logistic regression of the associations between sarcopenia and 90-day mortality (adjusted for age, sex, ASA class, surgery due to malignancy, and degree of intraoperative contamination (Mangram)).

q21.value: We will use p<0.05 as criteria for significance

q22.value: Only patients with preoperative CT scans will be included in this study

q23.value: Patients with incomplete or missing sarcopenia data will be excluded

q24.value: We plan to perform a subgroup analysis on obese sarcopenic patients compared to non-obese sarcopenic patients and non-sarcopenic patients on specific complications and mortality

registration_responses.q21: We will use p<0.05 as criteria for significance
registration_responses.q22: Only patients with preoperative CT scans will be included in this study
registration_responses.q23: Patients with incomplete or missing sarcopenia data will be excluded
registration_responses.q24: We plan to perform a subgroup analysis on obese sarcopenic patients compared to non-obese sarcopenic patients and non-sarcopenic patients on specific complications and mortality
registration_responses.q8.question: A retrospective cohort study was conducted including patients that underwent major emergency abdominal surgery at a single surgical center
registration_responses.q12.question: Major emergency abdominal surgery included open, laparoscopic, or laparoscopically assisted procedures performed on the stomach, small bowel, large bowel, or rectum within 72 hours after admission to the Department of Surgery for conditions such as perforation, ischemia, bleeding, adhesiolysis, deep infection, or obstruction. Patients who underwent multiple surgical procedures were eligible for inclusion if the primary surgical procedure was includable. Surgical procedures in relation to appendix, gallbladder, liver, spleen, or trauma surgery were not includable. Patients with more than one emergent admission during the study period, only the first admission was included.
registration_responses.q16.question: Sarcopenia was evaluated by the preoperative CT scan upon the relevant emergency admission. Patients without a preoperative CT scan, therefore, were excluded from this study. Only CT-scans within seven days of emergency admission were deemed relevant for sarcopenia evaluation. The preoperative CT scan closest to the surgical procedure was selected if several CT scans were available. Sarcopenia was defined as earlier defined 4 (5, 6) by evaluating the total psoas area (TPA) at the primary axial level of the third lumbar vertebrae where both vertebral spine were visible. The circumference of the psoas muscles and the Houndsfield unit of the marked area were registered to secure that muscle and not vessels, fat infiltration, or other tissue were examined. TPA was adjusted for height and weight and reported as mm2/m2.  Sarcopenia cut-off levels were  <385 mm2/m2 for females and <524 mm2/m2 for males, as reported 4. The radiologic evaluation was performed independently and blinded by two certified radiologists. A sample of 100 CT scans were randomly selected and evaluated by both radiologists.
registration_responses.q17.question: The primary outcome was the occurrence and distribution of specific complications (graded by Clavien-Dindo) among patients with radiologic verified preoperative sarcopenia. The secondary outcomes included 90-day mortality, 360-day mortality, and length of stay (days).
registration_responses.q19.question:
The study population will be stratified into patients with sarcopenia and without sarcopenia based on CT evaluations. The distribution of data will be examined with histograms and Q-Q plots. Continuous data presented by the median and interquartile range (IQR) and categorical data by proportions and percentages. 

Categorical data are analyzed by chi-square or Fischer's exact test where applicable and continuous data by students t-test or Mann-Whitney where applicable. Interobserver correlation between radiological sarcopenia evaluations will be evaluated by Kappa statistics. 

Univariate analysis of specific postoperative complications stratified by sarcopenia will be performed to identify possible postoperative complications that occur more frequently among patients with sarcopenia. Based on these univariate analyses we will attempt to perform multivariate logistic regression models (forced entry adjustment) with focus on 

- specific surgical complications (adjusted for age, sex, BMI, active smoking, intraoperative contamination (Mangram), and diabetes), 

- respiratory complications (including respiratory failure, pneumonia, pleural effusion) (adjusted for age, sex, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, active smoking, laparoscopic surgery, and BMI), and 

- infectious complications (adjusted for age, sex, and diabetes). Especially, we will see if patients with preoperative 

Finally, we plan a multivariate logistic regression of the associations between sarcopenia and 90-day mortality (adjusted for age, sex, ASA class, surgery due to malignancy, and degree of intraoperative contamination (Mangram)).

attributes.title: Sense of agency: the impact of task difficulty on the intentional binding effect in a standardized laboratory experiment

q1.value: Sense of agency: the impact of task difficulty on the intentional binding effect in a standardized laboratory experiment

q2.value: Christina U. Pfeuffer, Carolin Beer, Lin Brede, Annika Heer, Alexander Holicki, David Künzler, Judith Rudiger, Patrik Seuling, Sophia Wächter

q3.value:
The theoretical background for our study can be drawn from the scientific research about the concept of sense of agency, known as the subjective experience of self-causation. As an implicit measure for the extent of sense of agency the intentional binding paradigm can be used, describing the perceived temporal attraction of a voluntary action and its sensory consequences (see Moore & Obhi, 2012 for a review).
In this regard, the modulating effect of physical effort (unrelated to the intentional binding task) on the intentional binding effect has already been shown in a study by Demanet, Muhle-Karbe, Lynn, Blotenberg and Brass (2013). Supporting their hypothesis, an enhanced intentional binding effect has been found in conditions with high physical effort, more precisely when participants were holding a stretch band of high resistance while performing a task assessing intentional binding, in comparison to trials with a stretch band of low resistance. Conversely, another relevant study has been conducted by Howard, Edwards and Bayliss (2016) who found a contra-directional impact of physical and mental effort (unrelated to the intentional binding task), with high effort leading to a decreased extent of intentional binding, arguing that the depletion of cognitive resources through high effort tasks disrupts the implicit sense of agency.
The purpose of our study is to examine the impact of cognitive task-related effort (related to the intentional binding task) on the intentional binding effect in a standardized laboratory experiment to complement prior studies on task-unrelated effort. To do so, we compare intentional binding for an easy (responding left/right to the auditory targets “left”/”right”) and difficult cognitive task (responding with the same/opposite response depending on whether the auditory target is a vowel or consonant) which has to be performed to produce a tone effect. Similarly to Demanet et al. (2013), we assess the temporal judgement of either an executed action or a resulting consequence (tone) to determine the binding of action and effect, that is, the perceived sense of agency. Our research question therefore refers to the extent of intentional binding, more precisely the subjective compression of the temporal interval between our participants’ own actions and their actions´ outcomes. Comparing conditions of two different task difficulties, we hypothesize that stronger intentional binding, that is, a stronger sense of agency, should be observed in conditions with high as compared to low task-related cognitive effort.

q4.value:
Manipulation check hypotheses:
•	Participants´ mean reaction times should be longer in the difficult as compared to the easy task.
•	Participants´ mean error rates should be higher in the difficult as compared to the easy task.
•	Participants´ should rate the difficult task as more demanding as compared to the easy task in a post-experiment questionnaire.

Main hypotheses: 
•	Relative to the baseline condition, participants´ temporal judgements of their actions should be shifted forward in time more strongly for the difficult as compared to the easy task.
•	Relative to the baseline condition, participants´ temporal judgements of the effect tones should be shifted backwards in time more strongly for the difficult as compared to the easy task.

That is, tasks of higher difficulty should lead to an increase in the intentional binding effect as compared to tasks of low difficulty

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Within-Subjects design
Four block types : 
•	baseline tone block
•	baseline action block
•	operant block with action judgement
•	operant block with tone judgement
three factors:
1. block type (baseline vs. operant)
2. temporal Judgment (action vs. tone)
3. task difficulty (easy vs. difficult; i.e., task-related cognitive effort) 

Basis of this study design is a modified version of the intentional binding paradigm used by Demanet et al. (2013). As an adaptation, the physical effort will be replaced by cognitive effort (related to the intentional binding task), in order to examine whether similar effects on sense of agency in accordance with the intentional binding paradigm can be observed.
For the purpose of integrating task-related cognitive effort into the intentional binding paradigm, the difficulty of simple cognitive tasks will be manipulated, creating two levels of task difficulty. 
 
Stimuli and Apparatus
Participants will be seated in front of a 24” monitor with a resolution of 1920x1080 pixels and a refresh rate of 144 Hz in a quiet, neutral and sound-attenuated room. A keyboard and a mouse will be placed in front of the participants, so that both number board and mouse will be in the middle of the table and easy to operate. Participants ́ left hand will rest on the number board. Participants ́ right index and middle fingers will rest on the left and right mouse key. Participants will be wearing headphones during the entire experiment. The experiment will be programmed using E-Prime (2.0.10.356, Psychology Tools Software).
A clock with a rotating clock hand and typical five-minute-markers will serve as an orientation for participants´ temporal judgements of the action/effect occurrence. The clock has a diameter of 160 pixels (4.2°) r. The clock hand is sized 53 pixels and takes 2560 ms for one complete rotation. For every trial, the clock hand will start its rotation from a random position and disappears later in the trial (random interval after the participants´ reaction/the tone stimulus, depending on the trial type). Participants will judge the time at which an action/tone occurred by typing in the estimated minute count on the displayed clock on the number pad of the keyboard. 
Via the headphones, the auditory targets will be presented (~65 dB). For the easy task the German words “rechts” and “links” (German for “right” and “left”) will be used. For the difficult task, five consonants (K, P, M, Q, T) and five vowels (A, E, I, O, U) will serve as auditory targets. The auditory targets will be spoken by a neutral male voice in German language. This manipulation will be counterbalanced, so that half of the participants (according to their participant-number) will have to react to vowels by pressing the same key as in the previous trial (repeat; relative to previous correct response) and by pressing the opposite key when a consonant is presented (switch). For the other half of the participants, this mapping will be reversed. The first trial of each block will always be an easy task trial in order to set a start response.
In baseline tone blocks and operant blocks, a 600 Hz effect tone (100 ms, ~65 dB) will be used.

Procedure
After a brief task instruction, participants will execute four practice blocks with eight practice trials each. Each practice block represents one block type from the following main experiment and blocks are presented in a fixed order (baseline tone, baseline action, operant…..). For the practice blocks including actions, the tasks will be randomly selected from ten easy (five left, five right) and ten difficult trials (five switch, five repeat, while each vowel/consonant will be presented up to once). Trials (easy/difficult) will be intermixed in random order(except for baseline tone blocks which do not contain a difficulty manipulation). 
The experimenter will stay with the participant for all the practice blocks and answer questions. When all questions are answered and the task is made clear, the experimenter will leave the room and the participant will start the main experiment. At the beginning of each block a brief explanation of all blocks will be shown as a reminder and participants will be informed about the block type of the upcoming block.
After the practice blocks, participants will execute the main experiment with eight experimental blocks with 40 trials each. Every block type will occur twice and the order of blocks will be intermixed. For each block including actions, 20 trials will contain the easy task (ten left, ten right) and 20 trials will contain the difficult task (ten switch, ten repeat, while each vowel/consonant will be presented twice). Blocks including actions started with an easy trial. Then easy and difficult trials will be randomly intermixed.
Trial structure
At the beginning of each trial, the clock will be presented. The clock face will start rotating at a random position for every trial. After one to two clock rotations (duration random; 2560 – 5120 ms) the trial will continue.
baseline tone blocks will not include any task difficulty manipulations and serve as a baseline measure of the temporal judgements for the tone. 2560 to 5120 ms after the clock starts rotating a tone will be presented. The clock will then continue to rotate for another 0.5 to one rotation after the tone (1280 - 2560 ms). After that, the clock will disappear, and participants will be prompted to judge the time of the tone by estimating the position of the clock hand at the moment the tone appeared. For doing so, the participants will have to type the corresponding time (minutes on the clock; 1 - 60 minutes) via the number board and confirm with Enter. Then, the next trial will start.
All other blocks will include auditory targets and a manipulation of task difficulty. Baseline action blocks serve as a baseline measure for the action judgement. After the clock has finished its initial rotation,participants will be presented with the trial´s auditory response target (easy or difficult task, see explanation above) via headphones. Participants will be instructed to respond  as fast and accurately as possible. They will also be instructed not to delay their response on purpose (e.g., to make time judgement easier afterwards). 
Participants have to respond within 1500 ms from target onset. The clock will then continue to rotate until 0.5 - one rotation after the response (1280 - 2560 ms). If participants respond to early (prior to the target), incorrectly, or not in time, they will receive feedback in a red font for 1000 ms (“zu früh!”, German for “too early!” if they react too early; “Fehler!”, German for “error!” if they respond incorrectly; “zu langsam!”, German for “too slow!” if they don’t react within 1500 ms after target onset). After a correct response, when the clock disappears, participants will be prompted to judge the time of their action by estimating the position of the clock hand at the moment of their keypress by entering the corresponding number just like in baseline tone blocks.
The trials of operant blocks will be equivalent to baseline action blocks until participants execute a response. 250 ms after a correct response, a tone will be presented via headphones as an effect of their action. 0.5 to one rotation (1280 - 2560 ms) after that tone, the clock will disappear and participants will have to judge the time of their action or the time of the tone (constant per block and indicated beforehand), as described earlier.
Post-experiment questionnaire
Eight post-experiment questions will be posed after the main experiment. In order to assess whether participants are naïve to the purpose of the study and unaware of the study design, participants will be asked to write down their assumptions regarding the goal of the study (open response). After that, the perceived difficulty of each trial will be assessed via a five-point–Likert scale from one (very easy) to five (very difficult). There will be two questions for the action trials. One related to the easy task (“In den Durchgängen, in denen du selber reagieren solltest: Als wie einfach/schwierig empfandest du es zu reagieren, wenn du "RECHTS!" oder "LINKS!" über die Kopfhörer gehört hast?”) and one related to the  difficult task (“In den Durchgängen, in denen du selber reagieren solltest: Als wie einfach/schwierig empfandest du es zu reagieren, wenn du einen Vokal/Konsonanten gehört hast und die gleiche/entgegengesetzte Taste drücken solltest? “). Furthermore, one question will be aiming at the perceived difficulty of the temporal judgement (“Als wie einfach/schwierig empfandest du es, den Zeitpunkt deiner Reaktion/des Tons einzuschätzen?”). Then, there will be a question on participants’ attentiveness (“Wie aufmerksam warst du während der Bearbeitung der Aufgabe?”), again assessed via a five-point-Likert scale from one (very concentrated) to five (not concentrated at all). The next question aims at checking for possible tendencies of conscious manipulation in that participants might have postponed their responses to a certain point in time (“Wie selten/häufig hast du absichtlich deine Reaktion bis zu einem bestimmten Zeitpunkt verzögert?”). The last two questions of this post-experiment questionnaire will allow participants to mention experienced problems during the experiment or leave open comments on potential peculiarities (“Sind während der Bearbeitung irgendwelche Probleme aufgetreten? Wenn ja, bitte beschreibe diese Probleme.” and “Ist dir während der Bearbeitung etwas an diesem Experiment besonders aufgefallen? Wenn ja, bitte beschreibe diese Besonderheit.”). Responses to these questions will serve to determine whether participants perform their task correctly. Participants´ whose responses indicate that they did not comply to the overall task instructions will be excluded from analyses.
After the experiment, participants will receive course credit and will be informed about the purpose of the experiment.

q9.value:
The response mapping of the difficult task, requiring response repetitions/switches for vowels/ consonants as auditory targets will be counterbalanced between participants. Half of the participants (according to their participant’s number) will have to repeat their responses for vowels and switch their responses for consonants and vice versa for the other half of participants. 
The order of block types will be randomized and within each block (except baseline tone block) easy and difficult task trials will be intermixed with the constraint that the first trial of a block is always an easy trial.
Starting and ending clock position will be randomized per trial.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Participants will mainly be recruited via a local web-based study participation platform where participants can sign up for studies they qualify for on the system. In exchange for their participation, participants will receive course credit. Hence, the sample will mainly consist of Psychology students in early semesters of their Bachelor. Besides that, everyone without any hearing or seeing impairment may participate in this study. Nonetheless, it was insured that participants were unaware of the hypotheses by means of an open questionnaire at the end of the experiment.

q14.value: Based on the effect size observed for the comparison of intentional binding for the high and low effort condition in the study of Demanet et al. (2013) d = 0.413, we determined that 48 participants would be necessary to find an effect of this size for differences in intentional binding between the easy and difficult task with 80% power (GPower 3.1: Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009).

q15.value: Data collection will be finished once the data of 48 participants who fulfill the criteria for their data being included in analyses has been collected.

question.value:
1.	task difficulty: easy vs. difficulty (i.e., task-related cognitive effort)
2.	Judgement type: action (keypress) vs. effect (tone)

1.	Reaction times and error rates (in baseline action and operant blocks)
2.	Temporal judgements of the time of the action/tone

For checking the task difficulty manipulation: mean reaction times (correct responses, excluding outliers: > | +- 3 SD| from individual cell mean) and mean error rates (only incorrect responses) for the easy and difficulty task will be compared via paired t-tests. Task difficulty ratings of the easy and difficult task will be compared via paired t-tests.

For the main analysis, a 2x2 repeated measures ANOVA with the two factors task difficulty (easy vs. difficult) and judgement type (action vs. tone) will be executed. Dependent variable will be the mean difference in the time estimation between operant block and corresponding baseline block (Δ time = (judgement – true clock position)*2560/60). ). Outliers, trials deviating by more than 3 SDs from their individual cell mean, will be excluded.

q22.value:
Participants who correctly guess the purpose of study, indicate that they did not follow task instructions (post-experiment questionnaire), or show error rates more than 3 SDs above the average of all participants will be excluded from the analysis and replaced by further participants. 
Furthermore, the first trial of each block will be excluded from all analysis because of it’s predictable easy difficulty. In the error rate analyses, only the percentage of incorrect (not premature or late) responses will be considered. For reaction time and temporal judgement analyses, only trials with correct responses that do not deviate from their individual cell means by more than 3 SDs will be included.
Additionally, we will have to exclude trials where the temporal judgement would be recorded as much worse than it actually was. For example, if the exact answer would be 59 and the participant gave the answer 2, the actual onset would be 3, whereas the calculated Δ time would be -57 (see formula above). Therefore these trials will have to be excluded as they would distort the actual mean judgement.

q23.value: Participants who do not complete the whole experiment will be excluded and directly replaced.

q25.value:
Demanet, J., Muhle-Karbe, P. S., Lynn, M. T., Blotenberg, I., & Brass, M. (2013). Power to the will: how exerting physical effort boosts the sense of agency. Cognition, 129(3), 574-578.

Faul, F., Erdfelder, E., Buchner, A., & Lang, A. G. (2009). Statistical power analyses using G* Power 3.1: Tests for correlation and regression analyses. Behavior research methods, 41(4), 1149-1160.

Howard, E. E., Edwards, S. G., & Bayliss, A. P. (2016). Physical and mental effort disrupts the implicit sense of agency. Cognition, 157, 114-125.

Moore, J. W., & Obhi, S. S. (2012). Intentional binding and the sense of agency: a review. Consciousness and cognition, 21(1), 546-561.
