The clock will then continue to rotate for another 0.5 to one rotation after the tone (1280 - 2560 ms). After that, the clock will disappear, and participants will be prompted to judge the time of the tone by estimating the position of the clock hand at the moment the tone appeared. For doing so, the participants will have to type the corresponding time (minutes on the clock; 1 - 60 minutes) via the number board and confirm with Enter. Then, the next trial will start.
All other blocks will include auditory targets and a manipulation of task difficulty. Baseline action blocks serve as a baseline measure for the action judgement. After the clock has finished its initial rotation,participants will be presented with the trial´s auditory response target (easy or difficult task, see explanation above) via headphones. Participants will be instructed to respond  as fast and accurately as possible. They will also be instructed not to delay their response on purpose (e.g., to make time judgement easier afterwards). 
Participants have to respond within 1500 ms from target onset. The clock will then continue to rotate until 0.5 - one rotation after the response (1280 - 2560 ms). If participants respond to early (prior to the target), incorrectly, or not in time, they will receive feedback in a red font for 1000 ms (“zu früh!”, German for “too early!” if they react too early; “Fehler!”, German for “error!” if they respond incorrectly; “zu langsam!”, German for “too slow!” if they don’t react within 1500 ms after target onset). After a correct response, when the clock disappears, participants will be prompted to judge the time of their action by estimating the position of the clock hand at the moment of their keypress by entering the corresponding number just like in baseline tone blocks.
The trials of operant blocks will be equivalent to baseline action blocks until participants execute a response. 250 ms after a correct response, a tone will be presented via headphones as an effect of their action. 0.5 to one rotation (1280 - 2560 ms) after that tone, the clock will disappear and participants will have to judge the time of their action or the time of the tone (constant per block and indicated beforehand), as described earlier.
Post-experiment questionnaire
Eight post-experiment questions will be posed after the main experiment. In order to assess whether participants are naïve to the purpose of the study and unaware of the study design, participants will be asked to write down their assumptions regarding the goal of the study (open response). After that, the perceived difficulty of each trial will be assessed via a five-point–Likert scale from one (very easy) to five (very difficult). There will be two questions for the action trials. One related to the easy task (“In den Durchgängen, in denen du selber reagieren solltest: Als wie einfach/schwierig empfandest du es zu reagieren, wenn du "RECHTS!" oder "LINKS!" über die Kopfhörer gehört hast?”) and one related to the  difficult task (“In den Durchgängen, in denen du selber reagieren solltest: Als wie einfach/schwierig empfandest du es zu reagieren, wenn du einen Vokal/Konsonanten gehört hast und die gleiche/entgegengesetzte Taste drücken solltest? “). Furthermore, one question will be aiming at the perceived difficulty of the temporal judgement (“Als wie einfach/schwierig empfandest du es, den Zeitpunkt deiner Reaktion/des Tons einzuschätzen?”). Then, there will be a question on participants’ attentiveness (“Wie aufmerksam warst du während der Bearbeitung der Aufgabe?”), again assessed via a five-point-Likert scale from one (very concentrated) to five (not concentrated at all). The next question aims at checking for possible tendencies of conscious manipulation in that participants might have postponed their responses to a certain point in time (“Wie selten/häufig hast du absichtlich deine Reaktion bis zu einem bestimmten Zeitpunkt verzögert?”). The last two questions of this post-experiment questionnaire will allow participants to mention experienced problems during the experiment or leave open comments on potential peculiarities (“Sind während der Bearbeitung irgendwelche Probleme aufgetreten? Wenn ja, bitte beschreibe diese Probleme.” and “Ist dir während der Bearbeitung etwas an diesem Experiment besonders aufgefallen? Wenn ja, bitte beschreibe diese Besonderheit.”). Responses to these questions will serve to determine whether participants perform their task correctly. Participants´ whose responses indicate that they did not comply to the overall task instructions will be excluded from analyses.
After the experiment, participants will receive course credit and will be informed about the purpose of the experiment.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will mainly be recruited via a local web-based study participation platform where participants can sign up for studies they qualify for on the system. In exchange for their participation, participants will receive course credit. Hence, the sample will mainly consist of Psychology students in early semesters of their Bachelor. Besides that, everyone without any hearing or seeing impairment may participate in this study. Nonetheless, it was insured that participants were unaware of the hypotheses by means of an open questionnaire at the end of the experiment.

registration_responses.q19.question:
For checking the task difficulty manipulation: mean reaction times (correct responses, excluding outliers: > | +- 3 SD| from individual cell mean) and mean error rates (only incorrect responses) for the easy and difficulty task will be compared via paired t-tests. Task difficulty ratings of the easy and difficult task will be compared via paired t-tests.

For the main analysis, a 2x2 repeated measures ANOVA with the two factors task difficulty (easy vs. difficult) and judgement type (action vs. tone) will be executed. Dependent variable will be the mean difference in the time estimation between operant block and corresponding baseline block (Δ time = (judgement – true clock position)*2560/60). ). Outliers, trials deviating by more than 3 SDs from their individual cell mean, will be excluded.

attributes.title: The Influence of Caregiver Stress on Neural Correlates of Caregiving Behavior

q1.value: The Influence of Caregiver Stress on Neural Correlates of Caregiving Behavior

q3.value: Consistent responsive caregiving is essential for healthy child development. Caregiver adversity, including chronic stress, is known to negatively impact caregiving. Caregiving patterns, in turn, influence child neurobiological, cognitive, and behavioral development. The present study examines various neurobiological correlates of stress among caregivers, as well as pathways by which caregiver adversity may impact caregiver executive functioning, caregiving behaviors, and child neurobiological, executive, and behavioral functioning. To examine the relationships between these measures, we are recruiting 100 caregiver-child dyads (child age: 3-6 years) to participate. Caregivers and children come into the laboratory for one 3.5-hour session, in which caregivers and children complete a series of tasks, including parent-child interaction tasks, questionnaires, and cognitive tasks. Electroencephalography (EEG) is recorded during some cognitive tasks. We also collect a range of biological measures. Finally, caregivers are invited to participate in a follow-up phone call, in which they complete two additional measures.

q4.value:
We will test pathways embedded within Model 1 (attached), which illustrates the hypothesized relationships between caregiver and child measures. We will focus on testing the relationships and pathways outlined in the following aims, while also conducting exploratory analyses to look at moderators and additional relationships and pathways. Given the large number of measures being collected, we intend to report our findings in a series of papers rather than one publication. We recognize that our hypotheses are broad, which reflects the fact that this is an observational study with a large number of measures, and we will be exploring multiple hypotheses within each aim. However, all confirmatory hypotheses will conform to the general model (Model 1). 

AIM 1 (Model A): Determine the extent to which caregiver neurobiological measures, including proposed biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks, are related to caregiver self-report and behavioral measures, including performance on executive function tasks. 

Hypothesis 1a: Caregiver neural correlates of executive function will be significantly related to behavioral measures of executive function (e.g., proactive control). 

Hypothesis 1b: Caregiver neural correlates of reward will be significantly related to self-report of caregiver reward. 

Hypothesis 1c: Caregiver neurobiological measures of stress will be significantly related to self-reported mental health and wellbeing. 

AIM 2 (Model B): Determine the extent to which various sources of caregiver stress and adversity are related to caregiver neurobiological measures, including proposed biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks. 

Hypothesis 2a: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related with proposed biomarkers of stress. 

Hypothesis 2b: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related to neural correlates of executive functioning and reward. 

AIM 3 (Models C and D): Determine the extent to which various sources of caregiver stress and adversity are associated with caregiving behavior (e.g., degree of responsive caregiving), and identify neurobiological and behavioral mechanisms that mediate associations between caregiver stress and caregiving behavior. 

Hypothesis 3a: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related to caregiving behavior.   

Hypothesis 3b: Caregiver biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks will be significantly related to caregiving behavior.   

Hypothesis 3c (Model C): There will be an indirect association between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior, such that neural correlates of executive functioning and reward (as well as behavioral performance on executive function and reward tasks) will mediate the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior. 

Hypothesis 3d (Model D): There will be an indirect association between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior, such that self-reported mental health will mediate the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior. 

AIM 4 (Model E): Identify child neurobiological mechanisms that mediate the relationship between caregiving and child behavioral measures, including caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 4a: Caregiving behavior (e.g., responsive caregiving) will be significantly related to child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

Hypothesis 4b: Caregiving behavior (e.g., responsive caregiving) will be significantly related to child neural processing during executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 4c: Child neurobiological measures of executive functioning will be significantly related to child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

Hypothesis 4d: There will be an indirect association between caregiving behavior and child performance on executive functioning and language tasks, such that child neurobiological measures of executive functioning will mediate the relationship between caregiving behavior and child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

AIM 5 (Model F): Test whether caregiving behavior mediates the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 5a: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related to caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 5b: Caregiving behavior will mediate the relationship between (1) caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity and (2) caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

AIM 6 (Model G): Determine if, and the extent to which, caregiving behavior mediates the relationship between caregiver neurobiological measures and child neurobiological measures.

Hypothesis 6a: Caregiver neurobiological measures will be significantly related to child neurobiological measures. 

Hypothesis 6b: Caregiving behavior will mediate the relationship between caregiver neurobiological measures and child neurobiological measures. 

We will also conduct analyses looking at additional pathways within the model or related to the model (e.g., test whether child neurobiological measures mediate the relationship between child stress and child behavioral measures).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is an observational study. We are recruiting approximately 100 caregiver-child dyads. Each caregiver-child dyad comes into the laboratory for a session that takes approximately 3.5 hours and is invited to participate in a follow-up phone call that takes approximately 1 hour. The study is designed such that all participants complete the same tasks at the laboratory session and follow-up phone call. The caregiver and child versions of the Doors Task (described under measures; Proudfit, 2015) are counterbalanced between participants. Using an observational design will allow us to look at individual variation between caregivers and examine the relationship between measures among the sample in question (predominantly lower-income primary caregivers and their 3-6-year-old children).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Two research personnel (a research assistant and project coordinator) have been periodically checking the data collected from questionnaires, computerized tasks, and electroencephalography for quality assurance (e.g., to flag sources of experimental error). However, no research personnel have conducted analyses on the data. The only exceptions are (A) checking the income distribution to ensure that we have been recruiting an economically diverse sample, (B) checking the distribution for the NIH Toolbox List Sorting Working Memory Task and executive function tasks to ensure that there is some variability in performance, and (C) processing event-related potentials on EEG tasks using data from the first five participants. Besides these exceptions and quality assurance checks, we have refrained from looking at or analyzing the data.

question.value:
Population. We are recruiting caregivers (18 years old or older) with children between the ages of 3 and 6 from the Eugene/Springfield area. We aim to recruit an economically diverse sample. 
Recruitment Efforts. Recruitment efforts include distributing flyers (at community events, parks, libraries, etc.) and posting advertisements on electronic message boards and social media sites (e.g., Craigslist, Facebook). 
Payment for Participation. Caregivers are paid $70 for participating in Session 1, $10 for participating in the Doors guessing game, and $20 for participating in the post-visit phone call. Thus, caregivers receive $100 total if they complete both the in-person session and post-visit phone call. All payment is in the form of gift cards (Amazon, Fred Meyers, etc.). Children who participate receive small toys (e.g., bubbles, stuffed animals, stickers) at the end of the study, as well as small rewards (e.g., stickers) throughout the study. Participants who leave early are paid $25 per hour that they participated. 
Eligibility. Caregivers must have a biological child between the ages of 3 and 6 at the time of data collection. Caregivers are deemed ineligible if they are under the age of 18, are unable to be separated from their child for 45 minutes, report that they or their children have any physical or medical conditions that would make it difficult or uncomfortable to complete the assessment protocol (e.g., seizures, head wounds, lice), or are not fluent in English. In addition, the first 37 participants had to receive some form of income assistance in order to be eligible to participate.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 100 caregiver-child dyads. We will attempt to recruit up to 120 caregiver-child dyads, assuming that not all will complete all tasks.

q14.value: A power analysis for one proposed (and relatively insensitive) mediation analysis (the mediation indirect effect from caregiver stress to responsive caregiving through the caregiver observational reward positivity [RP] event-related potential [ERP]) was conducted using MedPower (Kenny, 2017), which estimates power of the indirect effect (ab). The direct effect from caregiving stress to caregiver observational RP (a) was estimated at ρ = .35 based on previous findings between caregiver report of parenting and the caregiver observational RP (Levinson, Speed, Infantolino, et al., 2017) and based on previous literature about stress and RP (Foti & Hajcak, 2009). The direct effect from the observational RP to responsive caregiving (b) was estimated at ρ = .34, based on studies that examined observational RP and self-report of reward and empathy (Fukushima & Hiraki, 2009). The direct path from caregiver stress to responsive caregiving (c’) was estimated at ρ = .37, based on preliminary data. Thus, assuming these relations among variables and using these path estimates, a sample size of 75 is needed to obtain .80 power to detect the indirect effect of stress on responsive caregiving through the mediator, caregiver observational RP. The proposed sample size of 100 (and up to 120) is somewhat arbitrary, but takes into account the likelihood that there will be notable (25% to 37.5%) data loss. This is not an unreasonable assumption given the challenges associated with working with young children and community samples. We are especially likely to be missing data from the post-visit phone session, which some participants may not complete.

q15.value: We will stop collecting data after 120 caregiver-child dyads have completed laboratory sessions. We may stop collecting data earlier depending on recruitment success; however, we are not making any decisions about ending data collection based on previewing the data.

Note: The following variables are sorted into categories based on the general constructs that they are intended to measure; however, there may be some overlap, such that a certain measure may fall within multiple categories. For example, a depression scale (e.g., the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale) could be used as a measure of caregiver adversity and stress, or as a measure of caregiver executive function and self-reported wellbeing, depending on context. Similarly, some items on the demographic form may be used as measures of caregiver adversity and stress (e.g., household income) and others may be used as covariates that do not fit into any category (e.g., age). Here, we include measures in the category in which they will be included for most analyses. 

Measures of Caregiver (and Child) Adversity and Stress
Adverse Childhood Experiences Questionnaire—Adult (Adult ACEs; Murphy et al., 2014). Caregivers complete the ACEs Questionnaire, which will be used to measure previous caregiver early life stress. 
Adverse Childhood Experiences Questionnaire—Child (Child ACEs; Murphy et al., 2014). Caregivers also complete the ACEs Questionnaire with regard to their child, which will be used to measure previous child early life stress. 
Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D; Radloff, 1977; Van Dam & Earleywine, 2011). Caregivers complete the CES-D, which will be used to measure depressive symptoms in the past week. 
Confusion, Hubbub, and Order Scale (CHAOS SF; Matheny et al., 1995). Caregivers complete the short form 6-item questionnaire with regard to environmental home stress.
Children’s Behavior Questionnaire Short-Form Version 1 (CBQ SF; Rothbart et al., 2000) a short version targeted at caregivers of children aged 3 to 8 years old. Caregivers are asked to rate their child on a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (extremely untrue of your child) to 7 (extremely true of your child). Caregivers are also provided with a not applicable response option when the child has not been observed in the situation described. 
Demographic 3.1 Primary Questionnaire. Caregivers complete a demographic form, which asks for general demographic information about themselves and their children (e.g., age, gender, race/ethnicity, educational history, income, etc.), as well as service utilization and resource insecurity. 
Economic Hardship Questionnaire (EHQ; Lempers, Clark-Lempers, & Simons, 1989). Caregivers complete the 12-item Economic Hardship Questionnaire, which will be used to measure the degree of economic hardship perceived by caregivers. 
Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory (ECBI; Eyberg, 1999). Behavior specific rating scales completed by caregivers that assess the current frequency and severity of disruptive behaviors in the home and school settings, as well as the extent to which parents and/or teachers find the behavior troublesome. The instrument distinguishes normal behavior problems from conduct-disordered behavior in children and adolescents.
Oxidative Stress Questionnaire. Caregivers complete a short oxidative stress questionnaire, which will be used to assess lifestyle patterns that might be related to oxidative stress, such as nicotine use. 
Parental Reflective Functioning Questionnaire (PRFQ; Luyten et al., 2017). A multidimensional self-report measure completed by caregivers that assesses parental reflective functioning or mentalizing. 
Parental Stress Index-4 Short Form (PSI-4 SF; Abidin, 2012). Caregivers complete the PSI-4 Short Form, which will be used to measure concurrent caregiving-related stress. 
Perceived Stress Scale (PSS; Cohen et al., 1994). Caregivers complete the Perceived Stress Scale, which will be used to measure concurrent global stress. 
Parent Sense of Competency (PSOC; Gibaud-Wallston & Wandersman, 1978). Caregivers complete the 17-item questionnaire that measures and assesses self-efficacy in parenting. 
Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ; Meyer et al., 1990). Caregiver’s complete the 16-item questionnaire that aims to measure the trait of worry in caregivers using a likert scale. This instrument has a strong ability to differentiate between GAD from other anxiety disorders.
Perceived Stress Scale (PSS; Cohen et al., 1983). Caregivers complete the 10-item questionnaire that measures the perception of stress. It is a measure of the degree to which situations in one’s life are appraised as stressful. 
Proactive Control Inventory- Preventive Coping Scale (PCI; Greenglass et al., 1998). 10-Item subscale of the PCI completed by caregivers. Preventive coping deals with anticipation of potential stressor and the initiation of preparation before these stressors develop fully. 
Proactive Control Inventory-Strategic Planning (PCI; Greenglass et al., 1998). 4-Item subscale of the Proactive Control Inventory completed by caregivers. The strategic planning instrument involves coping forms that depend on one’s own efforts to change a situation. 
Wheaton’s Chronic Stress Inventory (WCS; Turner, Wheaton, & Lloyd, 1995). Caregivers complete the Wheaton’s Chronic Stress Inventory, which will be used to measure caregivers’ perceptions of chronic stressors in their lives. 

Caregiver Neurobiological Measures
EEG is recorded from caregivers during the following tasks. For all tasks, continuous EEG is recorded using a 64-channel Geodesic Sensor Net and sampled at 250 Hz using EGI software (Electrical Geodesic, Inc, Eugene, OR). Before data collection, all electrode impedances are reduced to below 50 kΩ. All electrodes are referenced online to Cz and will be re-referenced to the average off-line. 
Adult Doors Task (Caregiver EEG). To measure caregiver neural responses to their self rewards and non-rewards, caregivers complete a modified version of the Doors Task (Proudfit, 2015) in which caregivers are told that they can earn money, which they receive at the end of the experiment. Images of two doors are presented side by side, and caregivers are instructed to choose one door using a response pad. Following the response, a fixation is presented, then caregivers either see an image of a green thumbs-up, indicating a monetary reward, or a red thumbs-down, indicating no reward. 
Child Doors Task (Caregiver EEG). Children complete a variant of the Doors Task during caregiver observation. Caregiver-child dyads are told that the child is completing a guessing game while caregivers observe their child completing the game. Instead of monetary rewards, children receive sweet and/or salty edible treats of their choice (e.g., Goldfish, raisins). Children are given the amount of treats they win during breaks between trial blocks. Caregivers are seated adjacent to their child and instructed to watch the screen while their child completes the task. 
AX-CPT (Caregiver EEG). Caregivers complete the AX-type continuous performance test, which is a cognitive control task that can be used to examine context processing and goal maintenance. 
Flanker (Caregiver EEG). The Flanker is a computerized inhibitory control task that is a direct assessment measure of both attention and inhibitory control. The task is administered to the caregiver via a desktop computer monitor and a response pad. The test requires the caregiver to focus on a given stimulus while inhibiting attention to stimuli (arrows) flanking it. Sometimes the middle stimulus is pointing the same direction as congruent order, and sometimes in the opposite (incongruent) direction. 
Oxidative Stress Measure (Caregiver urine and BMI collection). Collection of weight and height by scale are obtained to calculate Body Mass Index (BMI), which is a known confounder for oxidative stress. Caregivers assist their children with the urine sample. Urine samples are stored in a pad-locked-800C freezer located in a secure area of the UO Human Biology Research Laboratory. They are assayed for F2-Isoprostanes, a measure of oxidative stress, via gas chromatography-mass spectrometry. 
Caregiver HRV. HRV comparison of baseline/resting physiological recording to the task/assessment physiological recording throughout the entire visit. Caregiver and child complete a three-minute baseline assessment to collect resting HRV while watching a relaxing child short film (“Bedtime Lullabies and Calming Undersea Animation: Baby Lullaby”).

Measures of Caregiver Executive Function and Self-Reported Wellbeing 
Flanker (behavioral). In addition to recording EEG during the Flanker task, we collect behavioral measures, including reaction time and accuracy (across trials and by trial type). 
AX-CPT (behavioral and proactive control). In addition to recording EEG during the AX-CPT task, we collect behavioral measures, including reaction time, accuracy, d’ context, A-Cue bias, and Proactive Shift Index. 
Five Minute Speech Sample (FMSS; Magaña et al., 1986). The Five-Minute Speech Sample, sometimes referred to as the Expressed Emotion Interview, measures aspects of expressed emotion (EE), generally defined as a parent's emotional tone towards their child. The FMSS is administered during the follow-up phone call, during which caregivers are asked an open-ended question to prompt them to talk freely about their child for 5 minutes (e.g., “Tell me what kind of a person [child’s name] is and how the two of you get along together.”) The resulting audio recordings will be transcribed. Parental negativity and warmth expressed toward the child will be scored on a 0-5 point scale based on previously established scoring systems (Caspi et al., 2004; Kaugars et al., 2007).
NIH Toolbox List Sorting Working Memory. Caregiver complete one cognition working memory task on an electronic tablet (i.e. iPad), a List Sorting Test.  The List Sorting test measures working memory through participant recall and sequences different visually and orally presented stimuli.  

Measures of Caregiving (and Home Environment)
Responsive Caregiving. Caregiver-child dyads engage in a period of (a) free play, (b) clean-up, and (c) structured parent-child interaction tasks, which are video recorded. Videos will be coded using responsive caregiving measures. We are currently exploring reliable and valid measures of caregiving behavior.   
Parenting Sense of Competence (PSOC; Johnston & Mash, 1989). A self-reporting instrument that assesses parent self-efficacy. The instrument, designed for parents with children birth-17 years of age, was originally developed by Gibaud-Wallston and Wandersman (1978) with skill knowledge and value competence subscales but has been translated and revised by Johnston and Marsh (1989) for use with older children.
Parental Reflective Functioning Questionnaire (PRFQ; Luyten et al., 2017). A brief self-report measure designed to assess parental reflective functioning (PRF). PRF is the ability to treat the child as a psychological agent. Reflective function refers to an individuals ability “to hold others’ minds in mind”. This 18-item questionnaire encourages the caregiver to perceive both the self and others in terms of mental states, thereby making them meaningful, understandable, and predictable. 
StimQ2-Preschool (StimQ; Dreyer, Mendelsohn, & Tamis-LeMonda, 1996): The StimQ2-Preschool is an interview-based questionnaire designed to measure cognitive stimulation provided by the primary caregiver in the homes of young children ages 36-72 months (Mendelsohn et al., 2016). The measure is administered with the child’s primary caregiver by trained interviewers during the follow-up phone call. It consists of 81 items total, divided into 4 sub scales: Reading, Parental Involvement in Developmental Advance (PIDA), Parental Verbal Responsibility (PVR), and Availability of Learning Materials (ALM). The measure yields two types of scores: The Core Score includes the Reading, PIDA and PVR sub scores, while the Core + Supplemental Score includes the Core Score and the ALM sub score. 
Confusion, Hubbub, and Order Scale (CHAOS SF; Matheny et al., 1995). Described above. 

Child Neurobiological Measures
Child Doors Task (EEG). Caregiver-child dyads complete a guessing task variant referred to as the doors task (Foti,Weinberg, Dien, Hajcak, 2011; Proudfit, 2015). This task has been shown to reliably elicit an FN in adults during execution (Levinson, Speed, Infantolino; Hajcak, 2017) and during caregiver observation of child performance (Levinson et al., 2017). During the traditional version of the task, images of two doors are presented side-by-side and participants are instructed to choose a door to obtain a reward. In the dyadic version, adapted from Levinson et al. (2017), caregivers chose the door themselves on half of the trials (‘caregiver-active trials’), and observe their child choose a door on the other half of the trials (‘caregiver-observation trials).
Child Zoo Game (EEG). During the zoo game, children are instructed that they are helping zookeeper Annie help catch the escaped animals from the zoo (See Zoo Game Script). Children are instructed to press a button whenever they see a picture of an animal (Go Trials). In addition, children are told that orangutans are helping zookeeper Annie. Thus, children are told to not press a button when they see an orangutan (No go Trials).  Children complete 8 blocks of 40 trials with 80% Go Trials, and 20% No-Go trials.
Child Oxidative Stress Measure (Child urine and BMI collection). Collection of weight and height by scale are obtained to calculate Body Mass Index (BMI), which is a known confounder for oxidative stress. Caregivers assist their children with the urine sample. Urine samples are stored in a pad-locked-800C freezer located in a secure area of the UO Human Biology Research Laboratory. They are assayed for F2-Isoprostanes, a measure of oxidative stress, via gas chromatography- mass spectrometry.
Child HRV. HRV comparison of baseline/resting physiological recording to the task/assessment physiological recording throughout the entire visit. Caregiver and child complete a three-minute baseline assessment to collect resting HRV while watching a relaxing child film (“Bedtime Lullabies and Calming Undersea Animation: Baby Lullaby”).

Measures of Child Executive Function and Caregiver-Reported Behavior
Children’s Behavior Questionnaire Short-Form Version 1 (CBQ SF; Rothbart et al., 2000). Described above.    
Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory (ECBI). Described above. 
Child Zoo Game (behavioral). In addition to recording EEG during the Zoo game, we collect behavioral measures, including reaction time and accuracy (across trials and by trial type).
Child EF Touch (Pick the Picture, Somethings the Same, Houses). Multitude of tasks that measures executive function; attention shifting, inhibitory control, and working memory. There are eight tasks in the EF touch program and takes between 45 and 60 minutes. Often not all of the tasks are administered together due to the age of the child, therefore it is appropriate for the child to move around between tasks. In this study, the three tasks administered are Pick the Picture, Something’s the Same and Houses. The child responds via a touch screen laptop and the experimenter reads the directions from the external computer to the child.
Child QUILS. The measure contains three major components: Vocabulary, Syntax, and Language Learning. In the Vocabulary section, children are given a number of choices and asked to select the correct picture that matches a given word. The Syntax measure assesses children's ability to understand different components of sentence structure (e.g. who vs. where vs. what), using a similar tablet-based picture selection task. Finally, the Language Learning component measures children's ability to learn new words, presenting nonsense words in context and asking children to select the picture that matches what the nonsense word means.
N/A

Before conducting each analysis, we will obtain relevant descriptive statistics and graphs to examine distributions, trends, and relationships between variables. In particular, we will identify and correct for violated statistical assumptions. 

Our analyses generally include (A) general linear models and (B) mediation analyses. Additionally, we will test whether age and gender are significantly related to the variables of interest in each model, and if so, include them as covariates. Aims and hypotheses are copied in italics below, followed by the corresponding analyses. 

AIM 1 (Model A): Determine the extent to which caregiver neurobiological measures, including proposed biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks, are related to caregiver self-report and behavioral measures, including performance on executive function tasks. 

Hypothesis 1a examines whether caregiver neural correlates of executive function will be significantly related to behavioral measures of executive functioning (e.g., proactive control). 

Hypothesis 1b: Caregiver neural correlates of reward will be significantly related to self-report of caregiver reward. 

Hypothesis 1c: Caregiver neurobiological measures of stress will be significantly related to self-reported mental health and wellbeing. 

Analyses corresponding to Hypotheses 1a-c: We will run separate general linear models to test Hypotheses 1a-c, examining the relationship between neurobiological measures and caregiver self-report and behavioral measures. We will include neural measures as the “predictor” variables and self-report/behavioral measures as the “outcome” variables in the model, recognizing that these measures were collected at the same point in time. 

AIM 2 (Model B): Determine the extent to which various sources of caregiver stress and adversity are related to caregiver neurobiological measures, including proposed biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks. 

Hypothesis 2a: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related with proposed biomarkers of stress. 

Hypothesis 2b: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related to neural correlates of executive functioning and reward. 

Analyses corresponding to Hypotheses 2a-b: We will run separate general linear models to test Hypotheses 2a-b, examining the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiver neurobiological measures. We will include caregiver self-reported stress/adversity as the “predictor” variables and neurobiological measures as the “outcome” variables in the model, recognizing that these measures were collected at the same point in time. 

AIM 3 (Models C and D): Determine the extent to which various sources of caregiver stress and adversity are associated with caregiving behavior (e.g., degree of responsive caregiving), and identify neurobiological and behavioral mechanisms that mediate associations between caregiver stress and caregiving behavior. 

Hypothesis 3a: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related to caregiving behavior.  

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 3a: We will run general linear models to test Hypothesis 3a, examining the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving. We will include measures of caregiver self-reported stress/adversity as the “predictor” variables and measures of caregiving as the “outcome” variables in the model, recognizing that these measures were collected at the same point in time. 

Hypothesis 3b: Caregiver biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks will be significantly related to caregiving behavior.  

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 3b: We will run separate general linear models to test Hypothesis 3b, examining the relationship between (1) various caregiver biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks and (2) caregiving measures.  

Hypothesis 3c: There will be an indirect association between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior, such that neural correlates of executive functioning and reward (as well as behavioral performance on executive function and reward tasks) will mediate the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 3c: We will use a bootstrapping technique to examine the indirect effect of caregiver self-reported stress/adversity on caregiving through caregiver neurobiological measures (e.g., ERPs during executive function and reward tasks).   

Hypothesis 3d: There will be an indirect association between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior, such that self-reported mental health will mediate the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 3d: We will use a bootstrapping technique to examine the indirect effect of caregiver self-reported stress/adversity on caregiving through caregiver mental health. 

AIM 4 (Model E): Identify child neurobiological mechanisms that mediate the relationship between caregiving and child behavioral measures, including caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 4a: Caregiving behavior (e.g., responsive caregiving) will be significantly related to child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 4a: We will run general linear models to test Hypothesis 4a, examining the relationship between caregiving and child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

Hypothesis 4b: Caregiving behavior (e.g., responsive caregiving) will be significantly related to child neural processing during executive functioning tasks. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 4b: We will run general linear models to test Hypothesis 4b, examining the relationship between caregiving and child neural processing during executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 4c: Child neurobiological measures of executive functioning will be significantly related to child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 4c: We will run general linear models to test Hypothesis 4c, examining the relationship between caregiving and child performance on executive function and language tasks.  

Hypothesis 4d: We will use a bootstrapping technique to examine the indirect effect of caregiver self-reported stress/adversity on caregiving through caregiver mental health. 

Hypothesis 4d: Child neurobiological measures of executive functioning will be significantly related to child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 4d: We will use a bootstrapping technique to examine the indirect effect of caregiving behavior on child health, wellbeing, and functioning through child neurobiological measures. 

AIM 5 (Model F): Test whether caregiving behavior mediates the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 5a: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related to caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 5a: We will run general linear models to test the significance of the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity and caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 5b: Caregiving behavior will mediate the relationship between (1) caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity and (2) caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 5b: We will use a bootstrapping technique to examine the indirect effect of (1) caregiver self-reported stress/adversity on (2) caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks through caregiving behavior.    

AIM 6 (Model G): Determine if, and the extent to which, caregiving behavior mediates the relationship between caregiver neurobiological measures and child neurobiological measures.

Hypothesis 6a: Caregiver neurobiological measures will be significantly related to child neurobiological measures. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 6a: We will run general linear models to test the significance of the relationship between caregiver neurobiological measures and child neurobiological measures. 

Hypothesis 6b: Caregiving behavior will mediate the relationship between caregiver neurobiological measures and child neurobiological measures. 

Hypothesis 6b: We will use a bootstrapping technique to examine the indirect effect of caregiver neurobiological measures on child neurobiological measures through caregiving behavior.    

We will also conduct analyses looking at additional pathways within the model or related to the model (e.g., test whether child neurobiological measures mediate the relationship between child stress and child behavioral measures).

q20.value: We will utilize transformations as appropriate after identifying non-normal distributions. It is particularly likely that transformation will be required for heart rate variability and measures of caregiving, as these distributions tend to be non-normally distributed.

q21.value: We plan to use the standard p < .05 criteria for determining if the statistical tests and post hoc tests suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. We will use two-tailed tests. We will report all post hoc tests conducted.

q22.value: When extreme outliers are identified, we will first check to see whether this is due to errors in data collection and/or entry. Outliers that are not due to error will be removed from analyses. In general, outliers will be defined as data points that are two or more standard deviations from the mean. However, this may vary for particular analyses and measures for which the field has established alternative standards for identifying and addressing outliers. For example, for the AX-CPT, trials with reaction times greater than 3 standard deviations from each participant’s mean reaction time on correct trials will be removed, consistent with previous literature (e.g., Troller-Renfree, Buzzell, Pine, Henderson, & Fox, 2019).

q24.value: In addition to testing the relationships embedded within our central model, we will conduct exploratory analyses examining these relationships in the context of moderators (e.g., race, gender, age). We will additionally conduct exploratory analyses replacing some questionnaire measures with questionnaire subscales.

q25.value:
Our study is an observational study with a relatively high-risk sample and large number of variables. We try to be as specific as possible where we can, and would like to emphasize that all confirmatory hypotheses fall within the framework of the central model presented in Question 4. This includes (A) testing the relationship between constructs included in the model (e.g., examining the relationship between caregiver stress/adversity and responsive caregiving) and (B) testing the relationship between measures within constructs included in the model (e.g., examining whether one measure of caregiver stress and adversity relates to another measure of caregiver stress and adversity). Hypotheses that are inconsistent with the model will be reported as exploratory.

registration_responses.q1: The Influence of Caregiver Stress on Neural Correlates of Caregiving Behavior
registration_responses.q3: Consistent responsive caregiving is essential for healthy child development. Caregiver adversity, including chronic stress, is known to negatively impact caregiving. Caregiving patterns, in turn, influence child neurobiological, cognitive, and behavioral development. The present study examines various neurobiological correlates of stress among caregivers, as well as pathways by which caregiver adversity may impact caregiver executive functioning, caregiving behaviors, and child neurobiological, executive, and behavioral functioning. To examine the relationships between these measures, we are recruiting 100 caregiver-child dyads (child age: 3-6 years) to participate. Caregivers and children come into the laboratory for one 3.5-hour session, in which caregivers and children complete a series of tasks, including parent-child interaction tasks, questionnaires, and cognitive tasks. Electroencephalography (EEG) is recorded during some cognitive tasks. We also collect a range of biological measures. Finally, caregivers are invited to participate in a follow-up phone call, in which they complete two additional measures.
registration_responses.q4:
We will test pathways embedded within Model 1 (attached), which illustrates the hypothesized relationships between caregiver and child measures. We will focus on testing the relationships and pathways outlined in the following aims, while also conducting exploratory analyses to look at moderators and additional relationships and pathways. Given the large number of measures being collected, we intend to report our findings in a series of papers rather than one publication. We recognize that our hypotheses are broad, which reflects the fact that this is an observational study with a large number of measures, and we will be exploring multiple hypotheses within each aim. However, all confirmatory hypotheses will conform to the general model (Model 1). 

AIM 1 (Model A): Determine the extent to which caregiver neurobiological measures, including proposed biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks, are related to caregiver self-report and behavioral measures, including performance on executive function tasks. 

Hypothesis 1a: Caregiver neural correlates of executive function will be significantly related to behavioral measures of executive function (e.g., proactive control). 

Hypothesis 1b: Caregiver neural correlates of reward will be significantly related to self-report of caregiver reward. 

Hypothesis 1c: Caregiver neurobiological measures of stress will be significantly related to self-reported mental health and wellbeing. 

AIM 2 (Model B): Determine the extent to which various sources of caregiver stress and adversity are related to caregiver neurobiological measures, including proposed biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks. 

Hypothesis 2a: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related with proposed biomarkers of stress. 

Hypothesis 2b: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related to neural correlates of executive functioning and reward. 

AIM 3 (Models C and D): Determine the extent to which various sources of caregiver stress and adversity are associated with caregiving behavior (e.g., degree of responsive caregiving), and identify neurobiological and behavioral mechanisms that mediate associations between caregiver stress and caregiving behavior. 

Hypothesis 3a: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related to caregiving behavior.   

Hypothesis 3b: Caregiver biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks will be significantly related to caregiving behavior.   

Hypothesis 3c (Model C): There will be an indirect association between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior, such that neural correlates of executive functioning and reward (as well as behavioral performance on executive function and reward tasks) will mediate the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior. 

Hypothesis 3d (Model D): There will be an indirect association between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior, such that self-reported mental health will mediate the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior. 

AIM 4 (Model E): Identify child neurobiological mechanisms that mediate the relationship between caregiving and child behavioral measures, including caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 4a: Caregiving behavior (e.g., responsive caregiving) will be significantly related to child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

Hypothesis 4b: Caregiving behavior (e.g., responsive caregiving) will be significantly related to child neural processing during executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 4c: Child neurobiological measures of executive functioning will be significantly related to child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

Hypothesis 4d: There will be an indirect association between caregiving behavior and child performance on executive functioning and language tasks, such that child neurobiological measures of executive functioning will mediate the relationship between caregiving behavior and child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

AIM 5 (Model F): Test whether caregiving behavior mediates the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 5a: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related to caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 5b: Caregiving behavior will mediate the relationship between (1) caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity and (2) caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

AIM 6 (Model G): Determine if, and the extent to which, caregiving behavior mediates the relationship between caregiver neurobiological measures and child neurobiological measures.

Hypothesis 6a: Caregiver neurobiological measures will be significantly related to child neurobiological measures. 

Hypothesis 6b: Caregiving behavior will mediate the relationship between caregiver neurobiological measures and child neurobiological measures. 

We will also conduct analyses looking at additional pathways within the model or related to the model (e.g., test whether child neurobiological measures mediate the relationship between child stress and child behavioral measures).
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: Two research personnel (a research assistant and project coordinator) have been periodically checking the data collected from questionnaires, computerized tasks, and electroencephalography for quality assurance (e.g., to flag sources of experimental error). However, no research personnel have conducted analyses on the data. The only exceptions are (A) checking the income distribution to ensure that we have been recruiting an economically diverse sample, (B) checking the distribution for the NIH Toolbox List Sorting Working Memory Task and executive function tasks to ensure that there is some variability in performance, and (C) processing event-related potentials on EEG tasks using data from the first five participants. Besides these exceptions and quality assurance checks, we have refrained from looking at or analyzing the data.
registration_responses.q13: Our target sample size is 100 caregiver-child dyads. We will attempt to recruit up to 120 caregiver-child dyads, assuming that not all will complete all tasks.
registration_responses.q14: A power analysis for one proposed (and relatively insensitive) mediation analysis (the mediation indirect effect from caregiver stress to responsive caregiving through the caregiver observational reward positivity [RP] event-related potential [ERP]) was conducted using MedPower (Kenny, 2017), which estimates power of the indirect effect (ab). The direct effect from caregiving stress to caregiver observational RP (a) was estimated at ρ = .35 based on previous findings between caregiver report of parenting and the caregiver observational RP (Levinson, Speed, Infantolino, et al., 2017) and based on previous literature about stress and RP (Foti & Hajcak, 2009). The direct effect from the observational RP to responsive caregiving (b) was estimated at ρ = .34, based on studies that examined observational RP and self-report of reward and empathy (Fukushima & Hiraki, 2009). The direct path from caregiver stress to responsive caregiving (c’) was estimated at ρ = .37, based on preliminary data. Thus, assuming these relations among variables and using these path estimates, a sample size of 75 is needed to obtain .80 power to detect the indirect effect of stress on responsive caregiving through the mediator, caregiver observational RP. The proposed sample size of 100 (and up to 120) is somewhat arbitrary, but takes into account the likelihood that there will be notable (25% to 37.5%) data loss. This is not an unreasonable assumption given the challenges associated with working with young children and community samples. We are especially likely to be missing data from the post-visit phone session, which some participants may not complete.

registration_responses.q8.question: This study is an observational study. We are recruiting approximately 100 caregiver-child dyads. Each caregiver-child dyad comes into the laboratory for a session that takes approximately 3.5 hours and is invited to participate in a follow-up phone call that takes approximately 1 hour. The study is designed such that all participants complete the same tasks at the laboratory session and follow-up phone call. The caregiver and child versions of the Doors Task (described under measures; Proudfit, 2015) are counterbalanced between participants. Using an observational design will allow us to look at individual variation between caregivers and examine the relationship between measures among the sample in question (predominantly lower-income primary caregivers and their 3-6-year-old children).
registration_responses.q12.question:
Population. We are recruiting caregivers (18 years old or older) with children between the ages of 3 and 6 from the Eugene/Springfield area. We aim to recruit an economically diverse sample. 
Recruitment Efforts. Recruitment efforts include distributing flyers (at community events, parks, libraries, etc.) and posting advertisements on electronic message boards and social media sites (e.g., Craigslist, Facebook). 
Payment for Participation. Caregivers are paid $70 for participating in Session 1, $10 for participating in the Doors guessing game, and $20 for participating in the post-visit phone call. Thus, caregivers receive $100 total if they complete both the in-person session and post-visit phone call. All payment is in the form of gift cards (Amazon, Fred Meyers, etc.). Children who participate receive small toys (e.g., bubbles, stuffed animals, stickers) at the end of the study, as well as small rewards (e.g., stickers) throughout the study. Participants who leave early are paid $25 per hour that they participated. 
Eligibility. Caregivers must have a biological child between the ages of 3 and 6 at the time of data collection. Caregivers are deemed ineligible if they are under the age of 18, are unable to be separated from their child for 45 minutes, report that they or their children have any physical or medical conditions that would make it difficult or uncomfortable to complete the assessment protocol (e.g., seizures, head wounds, lice), or are not fluent in English. In addition, the first 37 participants had to receive some form of income assistance in order to be eligible to participate.
registration_responses.q16.question: N/A. This is an observational study.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Note: The following variables are sorted into categories based on the general constructs that they are intended to measure; however, there may be some overlap, such that a certain measure may fall within multiple categories. For example, a depression scale (e.g., the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale) could be used as a measure of caregiver adversity and stress, or as a measure of caregiver executive function and self-reported wellbeing, depending on context. Similarly, some items on the demographic form may be used as measures of caregiver adversity and stress (e.g., household income) and others may be used as covariates that do not fit into any category (e.g., age). Here, we include measures in the category in which they will be included for most analyses. 

Measures of Caregiver (and Child) Adversity and Stress
Adverse Childhood Experiences Questionnaire—Adult (Adult ACEs; Murphy et al., 2014). Caregivers complete the ACEs Questionnaire, which will be used to measure previous caregiver early life stress. 
Adverse Childhood Experiences Questionnaire—Child (Child ACEs; Murphy et al., 2014). Caregivers also complete the ACEs Questionnaire with regard to their child, which will be used to measure previous child early life stress. 
Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D; Radloff, 1977; Van Dam & Earleywine, 2011). Caregivers complete the CES-D, which will be used to measure depressive symptoms in the past week. 
Confusion, Hubbub, and Order Scale (CHAOS SF; Matheny et al., 1995). Caregivers complete the short form 6-item questionnaire with regard to environmental home stress.
Children’s Behavior Questionnaire Short-Form Version 1 (CBQ SF; Rothbart et al., 2000) a short version targeted at caregivers of children aged 3 to 8 years old. Caregivers are asked to rate their child on a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (extremely untrue of your child) to 7 (extremely true of your child). Caregivers are also provided with a not applicable response option when the child has not been observed in the situation described. 
Demographic 3.1 Primary Questionnaire. Caregivers complete a demographic form, which asks for general demographic information about themselves and their children (e.g., age, gender, race/ethnicity, educational history, income, etc.), as well as service utilization and resource insecurity. 
Economic Hardship Questionnaire (EHQ; Lempers, Clark-Lempers, & Simons, 1989). Caregivers complete the 12-item Economic Hardship Questionnaire, which will be used to measure the degree of economic hardship perceived by caregivers. 
Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory (ECBI; Eyberg, 1999). Behavior specific rating scales completed by caregivers that assess the current frequency and severity of disruptive behaviors in the home and school settings, as well as the extent to which parents and/or teachers find the behavior troublesome. The instrument distinguishes normal behavior problems from conduct-disordered behavior in children and adolescents.
Oxidative Stress Questionnaire. Caregivers complete a short oxidative stress questionnaire, which will be used to assess lifestyle patterns that might be related to oxidative stress, such as nicotine use. 
Parental Reflective Functioning Questionnaire (PRFQ; Luyten et al., 2017). A multidimensional self-report measure completed by caregivers that assesses parental reflective functioning or mentalizing. 
Parental Stress Index-4 Short Form (PSI-4 SF; Abidin, 2012). Caregivers complete the PSI-4 Short Form, which will be used to measure concurrent caregiving-related stress. 
Perceived Stress Scale (PSS; Cohen et al., 1994). Caregivers complete the Perceived Stress Scale, which will be used to measure concurrent global stress. 
Parent Sense of Competency (PSOC; Gibaud-Wallston & Wandersman, 1978). Caregivers complete the 17-item questionnaire that measures and assesses self-efficacy in parenting. 
Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ; Meyer et al., 1990). Caregiver’s complete the 16-item questionnaire that aims to measure the trait of worry in caregivers using a likert scale. This instrument has a strong ability to differentiate between GAD from other anxiety disorders.
Perceived Stress Scale (PSS; Cohen et al., 1983). Caregivers complete the 10-item questionnaire that measures the perception of stress. It is a measure of the degree to which situations in one’s life are appraised as stressful. 
Proactive Control Inventory- Preventive Coping Scale (PCI; Greenglass et al., 1998). 10-Item subscale of the PCI completed by caregivers. Preventive coping deals with anticipation of potential stressor and the initiation of preparation before these stressors develop fully. 
Proactive Control Inventory-Strategic Planning (PCI; Greenglass et al., 1998). 4-Item subscale of the Proactive Control Inventory completed by caregivers. The strategic planning instrument involves coping forms that depend on one’s own efforts to change a situation. 
Wheaton’s Chronic Stress Inventory (WCS; Turner, Wheaton, & Lloyd, 1995). Caregivers complete the Wheaton’s Chronic Stress Inventory, which will be used to measure caregivers’ perceptions of chronic stressors in their lives. 

Caregiver Neurobiological Measures
EEG is recorded from caregivers during the following tasks. For all tasks, continuous EEG is recorded using a 64-channel Geodesic Sensor Net and sampled at 250 Hz using EGI software (Electrical Geodesic, Inc, Eugene, OR). Before data collection, all electrode impedances are reduced to below 50 kΩ. All electrodes are referenced online to Cz and will be re-referenced to the average off-line. 
Adult Doors Task (Caregiver EEG). To measure caregiver neural responses to their self rewards and non-rewards, caregivers complete a modified version of the Doors Task (Proudfit, 2015) in which caregivers are told that they can earn money, which they receive at the end of the experiment. Images of two doors are presented side by side, and caregivers are instructed to choose one door using a response pad. Following the response, a fixation is presented, then caregivers either see an image of a green thumbs-up, indicating a monetary reward, or a red thumbs-down, indicating no reward. 
Child Doors Task (Caregiver EEG). Children complete a variant of the Doors Task during caregiver observation. Caregiver-child dyads are told that the child is completing a guessing game while caregivers observe their child completing the game. Instead of monetary rewards, children receive sweet and/or salty edible treats of their choice (e.g., Goldfish, raisins). Children are given the amount of treats they win during breaks between trial blocks. Caregivers are seated adjacent to their child and instructed to watch the screen while their child completes the task. 
AX-CPT (Caregiver EEG). Caregivers complete the AX-type continuous performance test, which is a cognitive control task that can be used to examine context processing and goal maintenance. 
Flanker (Caregiver EEG). The Flanker is a computerized inhibitory control task that is a direct assessment measure of both attention and inhibitory control. The task is administered to the caregiver via a desktop computer monitor and a response pad. The test requires the caregiver to focus on a given stimulus while inhibiting attention to stimuli (arrows) flanking it. Sometimes the middle stimulus is pointing the same direction as congruent order, and sometimes in the opposite (incongruent) direction. 
Oxidative Stress Measure (Caregiver urine and BMI collection). Collection of weight and height by scale are obtained to calculate Body Mass Index (BMI), which is a known confounder for oxidative stress. Caregivers assist their children with the urine sample. Urine samples are stored in a pad-locked-800C freezer located in a secure area of the UO Human Biology Research Laboratory. They are assayed for F2-Isoprostanes, a measure of oxidative stress, via gas chromatography-mass spectrometry. 
Caregiver HRV. HRV comparison of baseline/resting physiological recording to the task/assessment physiological recording throughout the entire visit. Caregiver and child complete a three-minute baseline assessment to collect resting HRV while watching a relaxing child short film (“Bedtime Lullabies and Calming Undersea Animation: Baby Lullaby”).

Measures of Caregiver Executive Function and Self-Reported Wellbeing 
Flanker (behavioral). In addition to recording EEG during the Flanker task, we collect behavioral measures, including reaction time and accuracy (across trials and by trial type). 
AX-CPT (behavioral and proactive control). In addition to recording EEG during the AX-CPT task, we collect behavioral measures, including reaction time, accuracy, d’ context, A-Cue bias, and Proactive Shift Index. 
Five Minute Speech Sample (FMSS; Magaña et al., 1986). The Five-Minute Speech Sample, sometimes referred to as the Expressed Emotion Interview, measures aspects of expressed emotion (EE), generally defined as a parent's emotional tone towards their child. The FMSS is administered during the follow-up phone call, during which caregivers are asked an open-ended question to prompt them to talk freely about their child for 5 minutes (e.g., “Tell me what kind of a person [child’s name] is and how the two of you get along together.”) The resulting audio recordings will be transcribed. Parental negativity and warmth expressed toward the child will be scored on a 0-5 point scale based on previously established scoring systems (Caspi et al., 2004; Kaugars et al., 2007).
NIH Toolbox List Sorting Working Memory. Caregiver complete one cognition working memory task on an electronic tablet (i.e. iPad), a List Sorting Test.  The List Sorting test measures working memory through participant recall and sequences different visually and orally presented stimuli.  

Measures of Caregiving (and Home Environment)
Responsive Caregiving. Caregiver-child dyads engage in a period of (a) free play, (b) clean-up, and (c) structured parent-child interaction tasks, which are video recorded. Videos will be coded using responsive caregiving measures. We are currently exploring reliable and valid measures of caregiving behavior.   
Parenting Sense of Competence (PSOC; Johnston & Mash, 1989). A self-reporting instrument that assesses parent self-efficacy. The instrument, designed for parents with children birth-17 years of age, was originally developed by Gibaud-Wallston and Wandersman (1978) with skill knowledge and value competence subscales but has been translated and revised by Johnston and Marsh (1989) for use with older children.
Parental Reflective Functioning Questionnaire (PRFQ; Luyten et al., 2017). A brief self-report measure designed to assess parental reflective functioning (PRF). PRF is the ability to treat the child as a psychological agent. Reflective function refers to an individuals ability “to hold others’ minds in mind”. This 18-item questionnaire encourages the caregiver to perceive both the self and others in terms of mental states, thereby making them meaningful, understandable, and predictable. 
StimQ2-Preschool (StimQ; Dreyer, Mendelsohn, & Tamis-LeMonda, 1996): The StimQ2-Preschool is an interview-based questionnaire designed to measure cognitive stimulation provided by the primary caregiver in the homes of young children ages 36-72 months (Mendelsohn et al., 2016). The measure is administered with the child’s primary caregiver by trained interviewers during the follow-up phone call. It consists of 81 items total, divided into 4 sub scales: Reading, Parental Involvement in Developmental Advance (PIDA), Parental Verbal Responsibility (PVR), and Availability of Learning Materials (ALM). The measure yields two types of scores: The Core Score includes the Reading, PIDA and PVR sub scores, while the Core + Supplemental Score includes the Core Score and the ALM sub score. 
Confusion, Hubbub, and Order Scale (CHAOS SF; Matheny et al., 1995). Described above. 

Child Neurobiological Measures
Child Doors Task (EEG). Caregiver-child dyads complete a guessing task variant referred to as the doors task (Foti,Weinberg, Dien, Hajcak, 2011; Proudfit, 2015). This task has been shown to reliably elicit an FN in adults during execution (Levinson, Speed, Infantolino; Hajcak, 2017) and during caregiver observation of child performance (Levinson et al., 2017). During the traditional version of the task, images of two doors are presented side-by-side and participants are instructed to choose a door to obtain a reward. In the dyadic version, adapted from Levinson et al. (2017), caregivers chose the door themselves on half of the trials (‘caregiver-active trials’), and observe their child choose a door on the other half of the trials (‘caregiver-observation trials).
Child Zoo Game (EEG). During the zoo game, children are instructed that they are helping zookeeper Annie help catch the escaped animals from the zoo (See Zoo Game Script). Children are instructed to press a button whenever they see a picture of an animal (Go Trials). In addition, children are told that orangutans are helping zookeeper Annie. Thus, children are told to not press a button when they see an orangutan (No go Trials).  Children complete 8 blocks of 40 trials with 80% Go Trials, and 20% No-Go trials.
Child Oxidative Stress Measure (Child urine and BMI collection). Collection of weight and height by scale are obtained to calculate Body Mass Index (BMI), which is a known confounder for oxidative stress. Caregivers assist their children with the urine sample. Urine samples are stored in a pad-locked-800C freezer located in a secure area of the UO Human Biology Research Laboratory. They are assayed for F2-Isoprostanes, a measure of oxidative stress, via gas chromatography- mass spectrometry.
Child HRV. HRV comparison of baseline/resting physiological recording to the task/assessment physiological recording throughout the entire visit. Caregiver and child complete a three-minute baseline assessment to collect resting HRV while watching a relaxing child film (“Bedtime Lullabies and Calming Undersea Animation: Baby Lullaby”).

Measures of Child Executive Function and Caregiver-Reported Behavior
Children’s Behavior Questionnaire Short-Form Version 1 (CBQ SF; Rothbart et al., 2000). Described above.    
Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory (ECBI). Described above. 
Child Zoo Game (behavioral). In addition to recording EEG during the Zoo game, we collect behavioral measures, including reaction time and accuracy (across trials and by trial type).
Child EF Touch (Pick the Picture, Somethings the Same, Houses). Multitude of tasks that measures executive function; attention shifting, inhibitory control, and working memory. There are eight tasks in the EF touch program and takes between 45 and 60 minutes. Often not all of the tasks are administered together due to the age of the child, therefore it is appropriate for the child to move around between tasks. In this study, the three tasks administered are Pick the Picture, Something’s the Same and Houses. The child responds via a touch screen laptop and the experimenter reads the directions from the external computer to the child.
Child QUILS. The measure contains three major components: Vocabulary, Syntax, and Language Learning. In the Vocabulary section, children are given a number of choices and asked to select the correct picture that matches a given word. The Syntax measure assesses children's ability to understand different components of sentence structure (e.g. who vs. where vs. what), using a similar tablet-based picture selection task. Finally, the Language Learning component measures children's ability to learn new words, presenting nonsense words in context and asking children to select the picture that matches what the nonsense word means.
