registration_responses.q19.question:
Before conducting each analysis, we will obtain relevant descriptive statistics and graphs to examine distributions, trends, and relationships between variables. In particular, we will identify and correct for violated statistical assumptions. 

Our analyses generally include (A) general linear models and (B) mediation analyses. Additionally, we will test whether age and gender are significantly related to the variables of interest in each model, and if so, include them as covariates. Aims and hypotheses are copied in italics below, followed by the corresponding analyses. 

AIM 1 (Model A): Determine the extent to which caregiver neurobiological measures, including proposed biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks, are related to caregiver self-report and behavioral measures, including performance on executive function tasks. 

Hypothesis 1a examines whether caregiver neural correlates of executive function will be significantly related to behavioral measures of executive functioning (e.g., proactive control). 

Hypothesis 1b: Caregiver neural correlates of reward will be significantly related to self-report of caregiver reward. 

Hypothesis 1c: Caregiver neurobiological measures of stress will be significantly related to self-reported mental health and wellbeing. 

Analyses corresponding to Hypotheses 1a-c: We will run separate general linear models to test Hypotheses 1a-c, examining the relationship between neurobiological measures and caregiver self-report and behavioral measures. We will include neural measures as the “predictor” variables and self-report/behavioral measures as the “outcome” variables in the model, recognizing that these measures were collected at the same point in time. 

AIM 2 (Model B): Determine the extent to which various sources of caregiver stress and adversity are related to caregiver neurobiological measures, including proposed biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks. 

Hypothesis 2a: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related with proposed biomarkers of stress. 

Hypothesis 2b: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related to neural correlates of executive functioning and reward. 

Analyses corresponding to Hypotheses 2a-b: We will run separate general linear models to test Hypotheses 2a-b, examining the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiver neurobiological measures. We will include caregiver self-reported stress/adversity as the “predictor” variables and neurobiological measures as the “outcome” variables in the model, recognizing that these measures were collected at the same point in time. 

AIM 3 (Models C and D): Determine the extent to which various sources of caregiver stress and adversity are associated with caregiving behavior (e.g., degree of responsive caregiving), and identify neurobiological and behavioral mechanisms that mediate associations between caregiver stress and caregiving behavior. 

Hypothesis 3a: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related to caregiving behavior.  

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 3a: We will run general linear models to test Hypothesis 3a, examining the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving. We will include measures of caregiver self-reported stress/adversity as the “predictor” variables and measures of caregiving as the “outcome” variables in the model, recognizing that these measures were collected at the same point in time. 

Hypothesis 3b: Caregiver biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks will be significantly related to caregiving behavior.  

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 3b: We will run separate general linear models to test Hypothesis 3b, examining the relationship between (1) various caregiver biomarkers of stress and neural processing during reward and executive function tasks and (2) caregiving measures.  

Hypothesis 3c: There will be an indirect association between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior, such that neural correlates of executive functioning and reward (as well as behavioral performance on executive function and reward tasks) will mediate the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 3c: We will use a bootstrapping technique to examine the indirect effect of caregiver self-reported stress/adversity on caregiving through caregiver neurobiological measures (e.g., ERPs during executive function and reward tasks).   

Hypothesis 3d: There will be an indirect association between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior, such that self-reported mental health will mediate the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiving behavior. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 3d: We will use a bootstrapping technique to examine the indirect effect of caregiver self-reported stress/adversity on caregiving through caregiver mental health. 

AIM 4 (Model E): Identify child neurobiological mechanisms that mediate the relationship between caregiving and child behavioral measures, including caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 4a: Caregiving behavior (e.g., responsive caregiving) will be significantly related to child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 4a: We will run general linear models to test Hypothesis 4a, examining the relationship between caregiving and child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

Hypothesis 4b: Caregiving behavior (e.g., responsive caregiving) will be significantly related to child neural processing during executive functioning tasks. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 4b: We will run general linear models to test Hypothesis 4b, examining the relationship between caregiving and child neural processing during executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 4c: Child neurobiological measures of executive functioning will be significantly related to child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 4c: We will run general linear models to test Hypothesis 4c, examining the relationship between caregiving and child performance on executive function and language tasks.  

Hypothesis 4d: We will use a bootstrapping technique to examine the indirect effect of caregiver self-reported stress/adversity on caregiving through caregiver mental health. 

Hypothesis 4d: Child neurobiological measures of executive functioning will be significantly related to child performance on executive functioning and language tasks. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 4d: We will use a bootstrapping technique to examine the indirect effect of caregiving behavior on child health, wellbeing, and functioning through child neurobiological measures. 

AIM 5 (Model F): Test whether caregiving behavior mediates the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress/adversity and caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 5a: Caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity will be significantly related to caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 5a: We will run general linear models to test the significance of the relationship between caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity and caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Hypothesis 5b: Caregiving behavior will mediate the relationship between (1) caregiver self-reported stress and history of adversity and (2) caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 5b: We will use a bootstrapping technique to examine the indirect effect of (1) caregiver self-reported stress/adversity on (2) caregiver-reported child behavior, caregiver-reported child health and wellbeing, and child performance on language and executive functioning tasks through caregiving behavior.    

AIM 6 (Model G): Determine if, and the extent to which, caregiving behavior mediates the relationship between caregiver neurobiological measures and child neurobiological measures.

Hypothesis 6a: Caregiver neurobiological measures will be significantly related to child neurobiological measures. 

Analysis corresponding to Hypothesis 6a: We will run general linear models to test the significance of the relationship between caregiver neurobiological measures and child neurobiological measures. 

Hypothesis 6b: Caregiving behavior will mediate the relationship between caregiver neurobiological measures and child neurobiological measures. 

Hypothesis 6b: We will use a bootstrapping technique to examine the indirect effect of caregiver neurobiological measures on child neurobiological measures through caregiving behavior.    

We will also conduct analyses looking at additional pathways within the model or related to the model (e.g., test whether child neurobiological measures mediate the relationship between child stress and child behavioral measures).
